I am almost ashamed I actually watched this. Watching this movie was an insult. When you think 'House of the Dead', where do you think it will take place? A house, as you would suppose. WRONG, the film takes place on an island, of course there was a house that was only there for 5-10 minutes, at most. Why would they call it 'House of the Dead' then? Because Uwe Boll has the biggest marketing scam of all time. Choose a popular game title then create a movie from that. The dialogue was very very poorly written. Almost no creativity was put towards the film.

There were so many continuity errors it is almost hard to keep track. An example is that weapons that the characters use will switch, sometimes they will even disappear. I don't know maybe the director forgot to give them weapons between cuts I don't want to know either.

The acting was so bad. There was very little expressions given in their speech and all responses were clearly faked. But it wasn't the actors' fault entirely. To go along with working for the worst director of all time, this had easily one of the most laughable scripts ever written that wasn't a comedy. The dialogue was just so bad. Here's an example that I'll use when the characters engage in a fight with the villain, who isn't a villain really:

Rudy: You did all this to become immortal. Why?

Castillo: To live forever!

I don't know why these lines are so horrible, maybe it has something to do with Castillo not even answering Rudy's question. All he did was define immortality, I manged to figure that much out on my own. No questions were answered and when something gets revealed that's supposed to shock the audience I was just as confused at the end as I was when trying to piece together similarities between the game and the film. Despite the horrible acting, it is better than the game's acting, but that isn't really saying too much.

Have I mentioned the fight scenes? They were just terrible. These people came to a rave on an island, they're just ordinary people like everyone else. But when they begin to engage in a fight all of a sudden the humans become martial arts masters. There was a 10 minute zombie showdown scene that is a perfect display on how not to film a zombie action scene. Nope, I take that back. That isn't how you should film an action scene PERIOD. The guns abilities to shoot are way over-exaggerated and it felt like an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie, minus the awesomeness of course. It's ridiculous what the weapons can do, I appreciate ridiculous but this was just pathetic. As well as the people becoming martial artists, well the zombies do too. If that doesn't say something then nothing does.

The movie was just cliché, WAY too many shots in which the camera would rotate around a specific character. The more the filmmakers used it the more quickly I wanted the scene to end. Deaths are never actually seen on screen, but instead they included clips of the 'House of the Dead' video game or the screen just fades into an eye-burning red, like your closing your eyes while looking into a light. All around the film was almost unbearable to even watch. Plus, using clips is just another example that the movie had no reason to be so different from the game because they had source material to work with.

My rating for this abomination: 1/10

If you want an accurate representation on how much this film has effected my taste for zombie movies, then I'll tell you. I have only seen one zombie flick since watching House of the Dead. Yes, it's that bad.

review_title: If you want to see monkeys wearing masks (a feeble attempt at portraying zombies) then watch this film.
review_detailed_main: After seeing this film i feel obliged to warn other potential viewers. The script has rivals in ridicule; the production quality and the acting. The story seems to be a mixture of a "teen-movie", horror/thriller and adventure/action; although the writer of the script obviously had never seen a teen, thriller or adventure in his life and was incompetent with the use of language and portrayal. The name is promising but do not be deceived; not only will this make you cringe, it will depress you. After a half-hour of this film i was seriously contemplating shooting myself. The only reason i didn't was that dying with that film in mind would have seriously perverted my peaceful rest. Please do not watch this film.

review_title: It Has The Feel To The GAME.
review_detailed_main:
Now because of the fame of the RESIDENT EVIL movie.There was just a matter of time before the HOUSE OF THE DEAD will kick in to the big screen.So Mark A.Altman and Uwe Boll teamed up to make an enjoyable Zombie movie that's just like the game.

The rave of the century is about to take place on an island off the coast.Where friends Rudy(Jonathan Cherry),Alicia(Ona Grauer),Karma(Enuka Okuma),Simon(Tyron Leitso),Greg(Will Sanderson),Cynthia(Sonya Salomaa),are off to.When they find out that the island is haunted by Zombies.They and fellow survivors Liberty(Kira Clavell),Casper(Ellie Cornell),and Capt.Kirk(Jurgen Prochnow),must battle the dead and learn about the history of Castillo(David Palffy),who haunted the island many years ago.

Now many people hate this film,but the people I know love this film.So I gave it a try.What I got out of it was a cool enjoyable Zombie movie.It was just like the game and made me want to paly it even move.To include on that,the game flashes didn't even bother me at all.I also know that the eating on humans where not viewed,but the violence on Zombies where wrost and harsh than any Zombie film.If you are a true fan of the game you will love this film.RESIDENT EVIL was still better this,without contest.

review_title: Run of the mill action horror with the emphasis on action.

review_detailed_main: Okay, lets start with the good stuff. Tons of violence and some pretty gory scenes, i enjoyed some of it and this is kind of like an action movie. Now for the bad. Uwe BOll directed it, begins with two minutes of clips from the game, literally gave me a headache and then it showed something that seemed to have absolutely nothing to do with the movie or maybe i wasn't paying attention. THere is a lot of bubbling water for on this island and you start to wonder why there would be a rave party on this island. The film is called "House of the dead" and based on some great arcade games, but they appear to only be in the house for about a half hour of the movie and remember those dogs that jump out of the fountain and attack you before you get into the mansion in the games? well, they are nowhere to be seen, nor are the guys running around with chainsaws that look like leatherface, and there isn't a gargoyle like thing anywhere. They could've just called it "Island of doom". The film had some "scary" scenes before the violence started but then it was all violence with heads being blown up and all that crap. There were girls that used their fists and feet to kill a bunch of zombies, the zombies also died from one bullet to the chest and could jog. The game is about zombie hunters, this is about teens and a coast guard and a crazy fisherman with a crapload of guns all stuck together on an island that is filled with zombies. One of the only things they did right was the "boss fight" at the end when they fought the king zombie, the good guys had an axe and he had a sword, not at all like the game but okay. These teens were too good at avoiding zombies and killing them as they had good aim with the guns, could dodge sword attacks and could kill them with their bare hands. In the last fight, the girl is stabbed and falls dramatically then gets up two minutes later as her friend is being strangled by the zombie and then she finishes it off and they live happily ever after. some mindless crap is involved in this movie and the sequel is less violent, but has some suspenseful elements and is actually in the college campus for the whole movie, with the exception of a few scenes building up to it in the beginning, that one had the zombie hunters and none of it was mindless gore. See the sequel and you can skip this one unless your looking for a nice piece of trash to watch on a Saturday night.

review_title: don't waste your time or your money

review_detailed_main: I rented this movie expecting it to be bad but even I was shocked at how bad it was. On top of the supremely idiotic premise of people gathering on a secluded island (a secluded island with a 'haunted' tag on it) for a rave, the script sounded as if it were written by a bunch of 10-year-olds. The little flashback to explain why the zombies were there was weak, at best, and all of the action sequences made no sense. The only (and I do mean ONLY) part of the movie I enjoyed was when the group was running up to the house and shooting their way through the hordes of zombies (many of them, like all those martial arts films, waiting until one zombie gets shot before attacking) - the Matrix-like filming was pretty cool, except the whole thing only works as a music video. Logically (and I mean horror movie logic), none of it meant any sense. Jurgen Prochnow, an actor of some merit, must have needed the money real bad. This deserves to be on the Bottom #100, no doubt about it.

This started out pretty OK. The production values were there and teh acting wasnt too bad.

Bt as soon as the first zombies show p the movie takes a really bad turn that it never recovers from.

The zombies suck. They look like machines. Red flashlights for eyes.

The rest of the film simply sucks. It's reall THAT bad.

Somehow there is a sequel to this garbage!

The only saving grace is the ht chicks who get naked.

This film is so much better than i expected it to be ... it's throw away nonsense that does exactly what it says on the tin... as mindless as the videogame is ... acting is mostly good, fit for the B-movie feel at least, action sequences are generally quite well done and the plot is the bare minimum needed to move us from one scene to the next.

Today, I finally got to see "House of the Dead" on TV. Yep, TV, so no boobies.

Had I seen the uncensored version with the boobies, I might've given it a better score.

This movie is NOT GOOD. Please, don't watch it. I don't care how many times you've beaten the arcade game, just don't watch it. The movie has little to do with the game. Even the stupid flashes of game play footage in the movie don't help. In the game, you went to a house and killed zombies. Little storyline, lots of action, many quarters down the drain. The movie has some sort of a story line that's not worth remembering.

Bad things: The kids want to go to a rave. First of all, they are rich white kids (with a black girl, to be fair I guess) who have nothing better to do. I've never been to a rave, but I thought that people who went to raves were...well, ravers! These kids did NOT strike me as X popping' Techno heads.

The kids, ravers or not, sucked. The characters were so thin that I swear my corneas got paper cuts just by watching them. The acting was so bad, I was cheering when they got attacked by the zombies.

Why was the rave during DAYLIGHT HOURS!? I thought raves took place in dark locations, like abandoned warehouses. Then the flashing lights have more of a dramatic effect on your ecstasy-induced stupor. No, this rave took place in broad daylight. The attendees didn't look like ravers. In fact, they looked like random extras semi-dancing around (which is what they were). And, the techno music sucked.

Gotta love the gun play, really. The kids went from being whiny losers to gun-toting Special Forces operatives. Just like that. They were SO skilled, that they never reloaded their guns. The dude with the Desert Eagle? He shot that thing like 15 times in one scene! He's so 1337 that a 7 round magazine means nothing to him! Even more awesome? There was no noticeable recoil either! Even when that one chick used the shotgun? Her arms didn't jump. THAT's what I call real ultimate power.

And the zombies sucked too. The zombies were apparently Navy SEALs in a past life, because they knew how to swim. One thing bothers me, though: When they were swimming with their heads above the water, you could see their breath. Zombies are cold dead magically reanimated flesh. No WARM BREATH CLOUDS.

And some of the zombies...looked like extras wearing face paint. I mean really, couldn't Uwe afford to get REAL zombies? Pssh.

In the end, don't watch it. Unless you're drunk. It'll probably be funnier that way.

Watched the film, thought story was lame, A Rave on an island which is home to the living dead. Why did they have to make the actors stupid, i'm just sorry that Juergen Prochnow as Kirk decided to act is this film, but on the plus side he was the only reason i watched the full film. Why did the director keep showing cuts to the video game, which was quite annoying after a few times. Too many zombie films have been made, this is not that special. Make up and special effects could have been a little better. Not worth rental unless its for a drunken party. Only * out of *****

Im not a big "B" film fanatic, i dont even think this falls in the B film genre, does it? Anyway, i watched this movie because i was pretty bored and didnt have high expectations, but im glad i DID see it rather than passing it up looking for something i thought was better. review_title: I haven't laughed this hard since i first saw "Dumb and Dumber"
Not nearly as bad as everyone thinks...
review_detailed_main:
To fully understand this movie, you have to look at the source content: House of the Dead (the videogame) is a terribly wonderful game (or wonderfully terrible) full of terrible voice acting, nonstop zombie guts, and a paper-thin plot. Translate that to a movie? What do you people expect?

The movie is exactly what it was meant to be, and as far as videogame to movie translations, this one is probably the closest to its source content than any other. They even splice images of zombies getting their heads blown off directly from the game, so that they can show it onscreen without getting an X rating.

Don't expect academy-award winning performances or anything like that. Expect what you get from the game. I can't even express how happy I was at the very end when the movie makes its SOLID connection with the game series. Fans of the game who payed attention to the "plot" will love this.

review_title: Shouldn't have come out in theaters
Not a bad idea... but the script is awful !!!
review_detailed_main:
OK we all read the reviews that it is bad. Yet, a lot of the flaming comes from people who in the first place do not appreciate B-action flicks.

So, let's be honest:

Pros: Jurgen Prochnow, good photography, okay directing for the action sequences (they are actually cheesy but fun), some cute actresses (Kira Clavel), gratuitous nudity in three separate occasions

Cons: Script is awful and characters are not consistent (e.g. the first death witnessed by the protagonists: one girl has turned in a zombie and twists the neck of one of the group of friends before she is shot by a cop: no one even looks at the guy who just died), the cutting and editing sucks and sometimes you don't understand what is happening (e.g. one second a guy is lying on a beach watching is naked girlfriend bathe, then the next second she starts drowning, and the next scene he has fallen asleep -- no sense of continuity)

So, it's not all bad, but what makes this movie tough to watch is that THE PRODUCTION DID NOT DO A GOOD JOB AT KEEPING AN EYE ON THE DETAILS. The movie is kinda fun but ruined at times but this lack of professionalism that transpires through the continuity inconsistencies.

And don't tell me it's because the budget is low. A movie like "The hills have eyes" was extremely low budget but there are no inconsistencies in the unfolding of the story.

Funny thing: in the DVD there is a documentary on Zombies in movie-making in which George Romero acknowledges difficulties to finance his own 4th "Dead" movie. And Uwe Boll has four projects in the pipe...

Sure, this movie is crap, but I don't think it deserves a place in IMDB's "Bottom 100." For one thing, it does have an admirable amount of exploding heads and other cheesy splatter. True, you have to sit through over an hour of boredom and stupidity first. But there are many, many movies that make you sit through a lot of boredom and stupidity without ever delivering the goop. Of course, it's also true, as others have noted, that "House of the Dead" suffers from a ridiculous overuse of "Matrix"-style camera techniques and the pointless splicing of scenes from the video game of the same name. The dreadful script, barely-there plot, and amateurish acting don't really help, either. Okay, so this movie does suck. But you could probably find 100 movies that suck worse than this one.

Oh yeah, and didn't Jurgen Prochnow used to have a real career?

review_title: Interesting but flawed action-film with a horror theme
I thought this movie was OK,certainly not the worst I've seen
This is a tough movie to sit through....
Believe the Hype, it is THAT bad...
review_detailed_main:
On my first chance to watch this infamous movie, I honestly can say that I was not expecting mistakes of this degree in a movie of this budget. It is as if they had given a good budget to a complete amateur. In fact, the entire film-making is completely the opposite to the one Boll displayed in his previous movie "Hearts of America" (2003). The only thing that could explain this serious mess is if Boll believes that his target audience is hungry for pointless and dumb scary movies. I hate to say it, but this movie is that: pointless and utterly stupid.

Loosely based on the popular video game, the movie tells the story of a group of teenagers who are going to a rave in an island, only to find that in the middle of the party, a group of strange people appeared and killed everyone. They will discover that the strange people who murdered the ravers is not really alive.

Even when the plot of the movie has nothing to do with the video game (only the fact that in both appear the Zombies), the basic idea had potential for being an average horror flick; but the script completely ruins every chance it has for being original and interesting by throwing in a series unrealistic situations that serve the only purpose of moving to the action scenes. This leads to a poor development of both the characters and the plot, as if writers Dave Parker and Mark Altaman were more concerned in getting quickly into flashy action sequences, cheap jump scares and pointless nudity.

The direction by Uwe Boll does nothing to save the mess this movie is, and even shows a talent to make the already bad written movie even worse. Not only displays a shaky hand-held camera work that makes it look amateurish, the poor edition and the quick cuts make the movie look like a lame MTV video.

I must recognize that Boll certainly had good intentions. The infamous use of footage from the video game could had been a well received idea by the fans of the video game, but his overuse of that resource gets tiresome and annoying specially if we consider that the footage has nothing to do with the scenes. Also, the bullet-time effect is well-used in a few occasions, but in the climatic battle for survival it ends up so repetitive that also ends up as a silly attempt for being innovative.

The acting is among the worst, not only because of the poor casting of young adults as teenagers; most of the time they look as if they had no idea of what they were supposed to do. Nevertheless, I must say that the few stars I'm giving to this are because of Jürgen Prochnow's performance. He retains some dignity and his character is the only one that is realistic and well played.

Overall, this movie is another good story wasted that will disappoint the fans of the video game. 2/10

...but sadly little else, thanks to the empty script. Uwe Boll's oft-bashed first US feature is not the train wreck many bandwagon-haters proclaim it to be, though it is certainly no master piece.

The movie starts out with a flash back monologue that lets the audience know bad things are afoot (like we couldn't already guess that) and then is off and running with some party scenes on a gorgeous island that concludes with a some skinny dipping carnage (is there any other kind). From there the film introduces most of the primary cast as they attempt to reach the "party of the year" on the island, only to find instead a zombie wasteland.

OK, the story pretty much sucks. Forget about the script taking chances, it barely can keep itself afloat with clique characters and some awful dialogue. Fortunately, genre regulars Jurgen (Seventh Sign) Prochnew, Ellie (Halloween 4) Cornell, Jonathan (Final Destination 2) Cherry, and the ever lovable Clint (oh just pick one) Howard are on hand to add the right amount of knowing winks to make things alright.

From the production stand point, things are fairly polished given the uber-low budget. Boll is actually able to scratch out some occasionally nifty visual effects to go along with the gobs of creature gore on hand. The zombies themselves are plentiful and damn near every one gets the ever loving hell blow out of them, much to my delight (why else do people watch these things).

It does nothing to advance the zombie sub-genre, nor does it effect a quality story, but the over abundance of zombie carnage ought to keep most horror fans happy.

6/10

With a 2 rating on IMDb and only 4% on Flixster, I was curious to see if it was really that bad. Damn I really need to stop being so curious! While it probably isn't the worst film ever made, it surely is one of the worst zombie ones.

At time it just seems like really bad music video. The flashes of scenes from the video game really don't help. Especially as this is meant to be a prequel of the games?

I gave this a rating of 2/10. The only reason it has a 2 not a 1 is for Jurgen Prochnow. He has some great comedic moments. Well great for this film!

Don't Be Curious!

Uwe Boll is, without a doubt, one of the worst directors of all time. The plot, the cinematography, the characters and editing are all miserable. I have seen this movie probably four or five times, just like with his other awful film Alone in the Dark. review_title: Yes, this is a really bad movie
review_detailed_main: Yes, this is a really bad movie. I suppose its real intent was to promote the video game, rather than stand on its own. The inter-cut shots from the game are jarring, and add nothing to the movie. But, then again, I'm not a gamer. The girls were cute, at least, and the one actor anyone had ever heard of, Jurgen Prochnow, was big-time slumming. His career must be over. As usual, in films like this, there were huge plot holes and outrageous continuity breaks. And, it seemed to me, the zombies in this film were awfully agile. Reminiscent of "28 Days Later" but those weren't really zombies. These re-animated corpses ran, jumped, swam, and even used weapons. What must George Romero, or your average Haitian, think? I'd have to recommend that everyone should run away screaming from the prospect of sitting through this movie.

review_title: The Worst Movie Ever-I LOVED it
review_detailed_main:
I enjoyed this movie so much, but not technically for the movie itself. This is one of the most god awful films ever made. My entertainment was totally based off the audience's reaction.

When I went to see this movie, the whole theater was full. People started leaving after the first 10 minutes. By the movie's end, there might have been 10 people left. My friend Matt and I were two of those people. One of the major reasons we stayed was to see how far into th movie each person in the theater could force themselves to sit through. This resulted in one of the most enjoyable film experiences of my life.

People have always told me that to get the full enjoyment out of "Freddy Got Fingered," I should only slightly pay attention to the film. To enjoy it, my main focus should be on the audience reactions. This is exactly how I feel about "House of the Dead."

There are two kinds of bad movies: 1. The terrible kind that bore the heck out of you and make you fall asleep and 2. The kind that is just soooooo stupid that it's actually funny.

For me, House of the Dead was the second choice. I admit that it was really, really stupid. But I had a great time laughing through the whole thing.

If you go into a movie like this expecting it to be good... well, that just shows poor judgement on your part. It's crap. Expect it to be crap, and you'll have fun.

As I said before, I am reviewing this film based on acting,budget,story,etc...and not on the GAME! The acting in this film was mediocre, we really didn't get to know the characters well enough for them to e lovable.Also, why try to add drama in a horror/action movie? That was the worst part of the film! The story was OK. The linear story direction was put well. Now the visuals had its great points and annoying points. It had great action scenes, especially the camera angles of the bullets flying and zombies dying! But the part that irritated me was the video game scene transitions. Why show the video game at all? In my opinion, it would have been better to just have the scene transitions normal and not show how the film compares to the game. So with all that together, it is a great movie to kill 120 minutes with.

review_title: Makes Resident Evil look like a work of art.

review_detailed_main:
You have to hand it to perpetually-deluded director Uwe Boll (who also graced us with "Alone in the Dark" and "Bloodrayne"): he has a certain sense of style...problem is, it's ingratiatingly inept every step of the way.

In "House of the Dead," his translation of a popular Sega game (see the banner?), a bunch of youthful fools (all looking like rejects from "The O.C.") accost ship captain Jurgen ("I was in 'Das Boot'!") Prochnow and crusty first mate Clint ("This is my best role since 'The Wraith'!") Howard to dance the night away at a rave on a secluded island. Once our fools arrive, the place is deserted. Zombies attack. Bullets are fired. Quick edits are employed. What little plot there is is forgotten as events move with a notable lack of logic (they hole up in the 'house,' run back to the boat, then run back to the 'house' again?).

With a script this awful, one can hardly blame Boll for doing endless slo-mo and 360-degree freeze frames...trouble is, this comes off as the MTV filler it is, and gets old after the first 2 or 3 times. Ditto the intrusive, random screen shots from the actual video game spliced in with the live action. As for the acting, the 'name' performers convey the whole bill-paying nature of the enterprise, while the 'no names' stumble through scenes with pitiable awkwardness (what is with that moron kicking a DOA ghoul?). The zombie makeup ranges from 'not bad' to 'pretty silly,' and the violence is so exaggerated it ventures into camp (though this certainly ain't no "Dead Alive"). And the "Matrix"-style gunshots are just SO 1999, man...

Ultimately, what's strange about "House of the Dead" is that it isn't the worst movie I've seen--in fact, the negative word-of-mouth is what drew me to it in the first place. Is it a 'good' movie? No, not by a long shot. But it isn't necessarily rock-bottom awful, either. While Boll is too slick and kinetic with his camera to draw favorable comparisons to the humbler Ed Wood, his films do leave a slimy, ectoplasmic residue that fascinates (in a morbid, 'how-much-worse-can-it-get' way)...

Side note: How in the world did George Romero and Tom Savini wind up in the behind-the-scenes featurette? I'm not complaining...though outdated (with Romero pontificating on what would become "Land of the Dead"), their presence is certainly the high point of the DVD package (watch/listen for a moment where the line, "the success of films like 'House of the Dead'" seems DUBBED IN to Romero's dialog).

This is one of the lowest rated movies on the site and its earned. No positives.

But, contrary to what I read in some of these reviews here, I laughed a lot at this movie (repeat: AT IT, not with it). To us, its so bad its good, no doubt.

review_title: It Could've Been Worse... Not Much Though.
review_detailed_main:
"House of the Dead" is a boring, unoriginal, all around bad horror movie. The plot (if it can be called that) consists of some 20-something year olds, who are going to the "Rave of the century" on some island. After missing the main boat, they get an old fisherman to give them a ride for $1000. Well, the rave is surely no "Rave of the century", it consists of a small stage, some porta potties, and a couple tents. Wow. That's one great rave. A thousand bucks well spent. Anyways, the kids arrive there, find blood splattered all over the rave, nobody there. What do they do? Of course, they go to find all of the partiers, assuming that it was all a big prank. Well, of course they are wrong, and they hole up in a small tomb-like house (that is about 20 times bigger on the inside than it appears from the outside) and fight the zombies to save their lives.

I was plain out bored with this movie. The director added a bunch of ridiculous shots from the actual video game the film was inspired by, why? I have no idea, but it looked terrible. The acting was boring and unconvincing, and the writing. Oh, the writing! What kind of person would go look for the "rave" after they arrive there and find the place to be splattered with blood. How likely is it that the entire rave wanted to play a big joke like that? This made me automatically hate the characters. And as they died off, we even got this cheesy still-shot of the camera revolving around them, and the screen fading to red. The person died, we get it, you don't have to include this little farewell.

Overall, "House of the Dead" is boring. It's unoriginal, badly acted, and nothing we haven't seen before. I think I'll give it one extra point for the semi-good zombie gore, but other than that, avoid this movie. 2/10.

For those who like goofy bad movies House of the Dead is a goldmine. (Well, it was in my case.)I liked and enjoyed this movie. Don't get me wrong, I wouldn't call it a good movie not by a long shot but it was enjoyable in such a goofy, ridiculous way that it was a pleasure to watch. There are plenty of bad movies out there which are bad in mundane, boring way which I would be tempted to give a far lower rating than the one this has been given. It has it all- bad acting of both the wooden and the hammy variety, over the top action scenes, bizarre and hilarious use of slow-mo and bullet time, weird editing choices, fake effects and unthreatening bad guys, gratuitous nudity, plot holes galore and scene after scene that make you wonder what the hell the makers were thinking. Best of all, the makers don't seem to have been trying to make a comedy or a self consciously bad movie so everything is done in a completely deadpan manner which makes it all the more enjoyable.

I usually recommended some movies even they're bad because it genuinely entertaining. But not with this case. This movie is so odd, neither a good action nor horror. I think this is a worse representation video game into a movie ever. Even Street Fighter and Mortal Combat is knock outed!

House of Dead suffering from a lot of plot holes, inconsistencies and bad acting. The direction is making it worse, when it lamely try to be hip by copycat other movies. He should be ban from any film making. Even the more amateurish director can make more proper film.

This movie is definitely a major joke. If you want to watch stalk movie watch Wrong Turn, if you want to watch zombie movie watch Dawn of the Dead and if you want to satisfy by big explode and kick-ass action watch The Matrix instead, because this wannabe is seriously sucks!

1/10 (and I'm being generous)

PS: Return of my money!

I'm not sure how or why, but I just had a craving to watch The House of the Dead one day. I had heard how bad it was, and saw pieces of it, but I just had this bizarre urge to watch it. So I did, and I think Uwe Boll should personally find a way to give me my time back.

I cannot even begin to try and decipher the plot and storyline of the film. It really is that bad.

Basically, a few young 20-somethings miss the boat to get to an island where the greatest rave of the century is apparently going on. They pay extra to be transported there, only to find no one at the party at all. From here, zombies attack and we find our reason for why no one is around, and why our characters need to stay alive.

Simply put, Boll should be barred and banned from Hollywood. If he touches anything in it, his hands should incinerate on contact. This man is a menace, and we need to lock him up or deport him before he continues his streak of cinematic abortions gone wrong (whioch has seen the likes of Alone in the Dark and Bloodrayne since then). This movie is just god awful, and I feel hard set at trying to use words to describe it.

There are shots of breasts, for the sake of showing breasts.

There is immense blood, shown, for the sake of showing immense blood (forget being true to the source, it's way too overdone here).

There is a sense of ridiculousness, for the sake, of being totally ridiculous.

This, all added together, makes for one the worst films in the history of Hollywood cinema.

I will concede though, I was impressed that the screenwriters found room to explain why there are random guns on the island they enter. Of course, they miss out on the explanation of how our characters know how to use these guns so accurately, and how they know how to fight like they could beat Bruce Lee himself. But then, if they bothered to explain that, they would have to explain how the characters know how to use other weapons like swords, or how they know how to bend gravity and use "bullet-time" to their advantage.

My brain can only be left at the door for so long before he needs to come back. These screenwriters, and Boll himself, made him find the need to come back and attempt to comprehend how completely ludicrous the entire thing is.

Yes, we understand this is a movie based on a video game. We do not need frames from the game spliced into the film to remind us. You also do not need to add the cheesy pan around the characters after they die. It's a classy touch, but an unneeded one. You also do not need to have random memory lapses by characters who are not even in the flashbacks being flashbacked to. You also do not need to steal from every film under the sun (from The Matrix, to Star Trek, to George Romero's ...of the Dead Quadrilogy, and that's just a skim from the top) to try and make this movie anything more than it already is. It screams of lazy screen writing, and bellows of even lazier greenlighting.

Even the half-assed "shock" ending is just that. Half-assed.

I looked for saving grace, and outside of a few humorous lines of dialogue (including one even mentioning Romero's films), I could not find any.

It's a terrible film, that just never should have gone past the screenplay. Everyone involved (and thank God most of the actors have only really done Indies) should be ashamed of themselves. Boll should have learned his lesson with this piece of trash, but only time will tell if he will stop making these continued cinematic crimes against humanity.

0.5/10.

(An extended review also appeared on http://www.geekspeakmagazine.com).

But it seems like he continues to learn by his mistakes and improve on his faults. And that is something the man deserves some credit for. Most people never does. review_title: If you like this movie, then I have no respect for your opinion
review_detailed_main:
"Kids" in their early 30s go to the world's lamest rave, held in the ruins of Jurassic Park. They are then attacked by the world's lamest zombies, and fight them off using concentrated stupidity and bullet-time. Then there's a vampire pirate and a helicopter.

People will try to justify this as a "Fun B Movie", "Something you aren't meant to take seriously" and that you should "Just turn your brain off and enjoy it".

Despite the fact opinions are subjective and thus cannot be right or wrong, these people are still wrong. While it is certainly a B-Movie, it's not fun, and the only way to enjoy it would be to think "at least these people are never, ever going to work again", except that they probably will.

The characters are totally bland cyphers who may as well be mannequins. This isn't "light" characterisation, it's non-existent characterisation, so I don't care what happens to them. Even when they should be scared or amazed - which the audience would at least relate to even if the characters redefine "2 dimensional" - the movie is too concerned with being cool to let us feel anything. There's so many bullet-time shots, video game clips (yeah, really), smug references to infinitely better movies and characters doing things solely so they can be put in danger that there's no truth to any of it; it's all soulless artifice that never progresses beyond the "A House of the Dead movie would be cool!" stage of its life.

No feeling. No life. No soul. A void. See, those "fun B-movies" that people love to go on about as some kind of justification for supporting tripe like this... they might have had bad effects, laughable scripts and wooden acting, but the people involved were trying to make something entertaining. The people who made House of the Dead were going on a $12 million self-indulgent ego-trip, and clearly didn't care what the end result was because, hey, wouldn't a House of the Dead movie be cool? Answer: Possibly, if it was made by someone else.

And, to cap it all off, they managed to take something as inherently cool as a VAMPIRE PIRATE, and then make him one of the most boring villains in history. If I made a movie, it would be about a vampire pirate killing the people who made this, then turning them into vampires so he could keep killing them. That would rule.

Negative aspects: Everything else. You can also find topless women on the internet for free, and without supporting the makers of this film, rendering the only positive aspect moot.

review_title: A modern day, 1970's style horror movie
review_detailed_main:
This movie is taking horrible criticism here on the IMDB. It is really strange to me to read such bad reviews from people who claim to be fans of old fashioned horror. I read one review that blasted HOTD and the writer wrote, "I was hoping to see something like an old Romero or Fulcci flick." HOTD is definitely not what you would call a "great" movie, but it does succeed in being similar to an old Fulcii style zombie movie.

The bottom line critique for HOTD is, if you liked Fulcii's "ZOMBIE," then you should like this movie. It really surprised me to see a modern movie done in such an authentic 1970's horror style. The movie even begins with gratuitous shots of HOT naked girls! The zombie makeup is VERY 1970. Most of the zombies simply have on white make up. The best zombies in the movie have a dirty brown latex "skull" mask. They look pretty good. Those are my favorite style of zombies. The dialogue and acting is total "camp" style. It is totally laughable. This of course means that you will either love this movie for its laughable quality, or you will hate it. I like campy horror movies, so I liked HOTD. I definitely believe that if HOTD had been released at some point in the 1970's, it would now be a cult classic, not unlike "LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT" or "ZOMBIE" or "THE HILLS HAVE EYES" or dare I say "EVIL DEAD."

One characteristic of the movie that definitely departs from the 1970's style is the use of MATRIX style bullet time effects. It's pretty fun to watch the high tech special effects in the middle of the zombie melet.

The big zombie confrontation in the middle of the film is a lot of fun to watch. This is the part of the movie when our gang is trying to fight their way through a crowd of zombies in the middle of a spooky graveyard to get inside "THE HOUSE." That scene was a lot of fun to watch, mindless as it was. It is a battle-royale with zombies exploding and people being torn limb from limb. The sequence went on much longer than I thought it would! They just keep on fighting and fighting and blood and body parts go flying all over the place. COOL!

This movie is getting slammed in the reviews, and I think that is unfortunate. The movie feels very much like a low-budget independent horror movie. So if you like those, you will probably like HOTD. I think one of the reasons the movie is not well recieved is because people are expecting something more like "RESIDENT EVIL." If you are going to watch this movie, try not to take it so seriously. It really reminded me a lot of "ZOMBIE" which I enjoyed, and also "CHILDREN SHOULDN'T PLAY WITH DEAD THINGS." If you are looking for low budget fun and a zombie halocaustic setting, then you will like this movie...as long as you have a sense of humor about what you are watching!

A little word to the other IMDB reviewers: LIGHTEN UP A LITTLE, GUYS!

review_title: Officially the worst game movie or any movie

review_detailed_main:
This movie is way ahead of its time; the appropriate time would be when I'm so senile just planting me in front of a television and its flashing light puts a smile of my drooling face.

The House of the Dead, named for the `house music' played during the movie's pivotal rave party rather then after any architectural feature, is certainly the weakest of Clint Howard's one armed fishermen tales of the Pacific North West.

Bare breasts, yet a weak selection of off-the-rack firearms make this a difficult movie to reconcile or compare to other representatives of the zombie island film genre (with the notable exception of `Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island' of course). Instead, it would better to compare this cinematic gem with what I ate for lunch today. My lunch was much better.

The digital special effects were quite impressive; for instance Jurgen Prochnow was added digitally in the otherwise uncastable role of Captain Kirk, the fifteen hundred dollar ferryman to the stars. The visual transition from movie to video game to staring at the ceiling of the theater wishing it would all end was seamless, and should also really warrant some special technical consideration.

2/10

I can only say one good thing about House of the Dead. It was playing on Sci Fi, so I didn't have to pay extra to see it.

That said, I want that two hours of my life back.

From the ridiculous premise (a massive rave on an island only accessible via fishing trawler or your seat cushion, which doubles as a flotation device) to the leaden dialogue (especially as delivered by the cop, who is less expressive than Al Gore in 2000) to the video game footage spliced into the film (yes, from Sega's 1997 arcade game of the same title) . . . it's truly craptacular! They even manage to create an ASHesque character. Imagine the result if Bruce Campbell and Carter from Trading Spaces had a love child, only without the wit OR the power tools of either. They could at least have given him a rechargeable drill with a spade bit, if a chainsaw wasn't handy.

This movie isn't bad in a "so bad it's good" way. Not in a "bad enough to laugh at and enjoy" way.

It's just bad.

review_title: Simple, unchallenging entertainment that doesn't pretend to be something it isn't.
review_detailed_main:
I read the IMDb scores and reviews before watching House of the Dead and thought I'd watch to see just how bad it was. I was pleasantly surprised to spend an hour and a half watching a decent film; much better than a lot of big budget stuff, such as some of the Hollywood remakes of some horror classics. So long as you understand the budget background, and find lower budget films entertaining - such as great Brit Flicks like Shawn of the Dead -there's something worth watching here. I'm guessing this was more of a Canadian film than USA, and that seems to show in the whole manner of the film. I've often found that many Canadian movies to have some magic ingredient that makes them stand out, but an ingredient that doesn't taste good to the masses.

The effects were appropriate for the low budget background; don't expect the sort of stuff you see in Resident Evil. Apart from too much dialogue to the audience at the beginning, the direction and production quality was good. The acting was appropriate for the roles without being award quality; bimbos were bimbos, tough guys were tough guys, etc. The lead role (J Cherry) was the usual brooding thoughtful hero type.

Simple, unchallenging entertainment that doesn't pretend to be something it isn't. If you are a fan of the original game or game genre you should like it.

review_title: The one film that I think should be burned and forgotten
review_detailed_main:
OK, first off let me state two things before I start the review.

2 - I am a huge zombie movie fan, I love all the Romero films, including the Dawn (04) remake. I have seen many zombie films in my lifetime, many of them brilliant, others not so.

2 - I have seen many awful film; Hercules in New York, Garfield, Alone In The Dark and Baby Genius are to name but a few.

When having mates round my house for a "movie marathon" night (usually about 6 films in a row),we usually go for 1 film that we know is going to be awfully crap. So on New Year's Eve, 2005. We rented Uwe Boll's "House Of The Dead", knowing full well what critic's have said, knowing full well where it is placed in IMDb's worst all time films. Yet, we watched, and why? for the comic value. We rent bad films to laugh at them. If you think you're going to be able to watch a bad film and take it seriously, or mad. However, watch it with the intention of laughing at it (especially with a few mates) and your guaranteed a good time.

This was not the case with this film. It went straight passed "so bad its funny" straight to the disastrous "so bad its annoying". Uwe Boll has tried to make the film adaptation of the classic arcade shooter "House Of The Dead", which, any director would try and do with care. Look at "Mortal Kombat" and "Doom", the directors and writers clearly know the story (or lack of) of the games, and turned it into a film, knowing what it is the audience wants to sees (be it fighting or monster demons.)

Yet with this monstrosity, Boll has taken the franchise with the pure knowledge that the ENTIRE of his film will consist of "zombies being shot"...and that's what he delivers. But even that simple concept is badly done. The zombies are extremely badly designed and created and is laughable when they're seen swimming, jumping (especially off clearly visible jump pads), running and swinging / throwing axes.

Almost as bad is the characterisation. OK, so we can clearly expect that there's going to be almost none of it, given it's a little horror film. But let me ask you a few questions:

1 - Would you pay £1000 to go to ONE rave? 2 - Once realising the rave has been interrupted and the people have disappeared, would you stay, drink and attempt to have sex? 3 - If you were a simple teenager / young adult, and you've seen the chaos of your friends being killed by zombies - would you have the mental and physical strength to pick up serious hardware, and go all "matrix" on zombies?

If you answered "no" to all of those questions, then you can carry on reading. If you answered "yes" to any of them and wasn't joking, shame on you.

This film has no reason to be this bad. Given that Uwe Boll (suposedly) had a decent budget and had one 1st class actor (jurgen prochnow - sorry about spelling)he should have been able to create a good film. The only way that he puts in references to the arcade game, is through very quick 1 second shots of the game itself, with zombies being shot or monsters attacking the screen. This, instead of being thoughtfully placed or helping the film progress, just makes it all the more annoying and adds to the temptation to pressing the "off" button on the DVD player.

This film cannot be stated as a "one off bad film" from the director, he has followed on to make "Alone In The Dark" and "Bloodrayne", both of them under the score of 3.0 on this website. It's sad to see his later plans are good ideas, because its hard to stray from the truth that he will utterly screw them up.

Resist this film at all cost, it does not deserve your money.

Resist EVERY Uwe Boll film at all cost, he does not deserve your money.

review_title: Makes the game an Oscar winner by comparison.
review_detailed_main:
"House of the Dead" is a great game. It may have ripped off "Resident Evil," but by that logic, you can say "Resident Evil" ripped off George A. Romero, and so on. So when I initially heard that they were making a movie based on one of my favorite first-person shooter games, I was excited. But then I read over and over again how horrible it was, and decided to wait until it was on cable rather than blow money on it in the theater. When I finally saw it, I realized that there were no words to describe how horrible it was. Since it's based on a video game, I never expected an Oscar winner, but for God's sake - I've seen some bad movies based on video games, but this one is even worse than "Double Dragon," and believe me, that's pretty bad. You almost have to TRY to make a movie this bad.

Uwe Boll, you are not a director. I know you narcissistically think of yourself as "the best in the business," but sooner or later, reality has to step in. In the meantime, here's a few hints to help with that reality check:

1. Using the Sega logo at the rave didn't make any sense. Honestly, what band is going to have Sega as a sponsor? The New Kids On The Block reunion tour?

2. Placing young rave-goers in a sudden horrific predicament won't automatically make them highly-trained counter-terrorism operatives.

3. The game is called "House of the Dead," not "Shack of the Dead." The house in the game is an enormous mansion, not some dilapidated pile of crap in the middle of no where.

4. Having Clint Howard repeat his dialog in a weird voice was just annoying as all Hell, not creepy or funny, whichever you were going for. Just let Clint Howard be Clint Howard.

5. I got the "U-boat" and "Captain Kirk" jokes concerning Jürgen Prochnow. They sucked. The only way anything in this movie was funny was unintentionally.

6. If people want to see scenes from the game, they'll pay fifty cents to play it, not six dollars to see them as cut scenes in a movie.

7. The zombies didn't run in the game. Why should they in the movie? Face it, Boll - you're no Zack Snyder.

8. Making zombies the leading authorities on tree-grabbing doesn't do much to make them terrifying.

9. Chances are that ancient Spanish explorers would be speaking Spanish to each other, not English. Ever hear of subtitles?

10. The mere mention of the genius of George A. Romero in this cinematic waste is almost unforgivable.

As for my fellow movie-goers - especially compulsive lovers of zombie films such as myself - if you have absolutely nothing else to do, you might want to check out "House of the Dead" for a few laughs. Nothing else. And for the love of God, if you have to see it, see it on cable; don't rent it. I've seen plenty of excellent zombie films as well as plenty of excessively cheesy ones, and I'll tell you right now, S. William Hinzman's "Flesheater" was better than this one. At least that one didn't try to be something it wasn't - a cheesy zombie film. A comatose barnacle could make something better than this. The very fact that Uwe Boll didn't direct "House of the Dead 2: Dead Aim" implies that there may actually be hope for it.

review_title: A good movie for those who truly appreciate cheesy horror and the original video game
review_detailed_main:
While not up there with some of the better zombie movies of our day I still think this film manages to hold up well for what is is. The action sequences and camera work during them were pretty nifty, and the video game footage interspersed was a novel idea. The acting and dialog, while on the surface seem wooden, may actually be an attempt to shadow what happens in a game- with characters saying things that would seem stupid in a real life situation, but are exactly the kinds of things you expect to hear from video game characters ("Guys, check out this book. Looks pretty old, maybe it'll help us!"). A lot of the camera work and in particular the work during and after the death scenes also drive the point home that yes, this movie is based on the concept of a game. In terms of upholding the cheesy horror movie tradition this film does fairly well, with plenty of pointless female nudity, plenty of over the top gore and plenty of lame dialog (whether intended or not).

Definitely a movie to avoid if you don't have an appreciation for B-grade flicks, but for those of us who love our horror as bad as it gets, don't go passing this one up.

Who cares about the plot? Plots are overrated. What really makes a great movie is great action and revolutionary 360 degree spinning of the camera. What an awesome film.

Okay, enough of that. Only in an alternate universe will this piece of horse manure be considered an actual movie, let alone a good one.

review_title: Unwatchable. Stopped this movie after 5 minutes of viewing.
You know, I learned something today...
review_detailed_main:
I rated this movie a one out of ten for several reasons. No, for the sake of my money and sanity, I have not actually seen this movie. No one can prove to me otherwise that Uwe Boll is talented in any degree: whether it's a video game 'adaptation' or not. I choose not to see any of his movies. Am I missing out? Nah, not really. I can make my own using an extremely light budget of Windows XP Movie Maker, some mp3s, and poorly drawn animation - and get at least a 6 or a 7 on IMDb for trying.

What amazes me the most though about this, is that when you look at this movie - a lot of people have also called the Super Mario Bros. and Street Fighter movie to be very bad. But here is the thing: they stayed closer to the actual material than this movie ever did - and I've played House of the Dead at the arcades to know that this movie has nothing to do with the game at all. The only thing kept from the game are the zombies. This makes me wonder now, A) Why are people going to Uwe Boll to direct versions of their video games on film? Hasn't the poor performance pretty much proved enough? and B) Why waste time with Uwe Boll? Instead of walking in to get a George A. Romero-inspired masterpiece, we get the stereotypical zombie blaxploitation films of the 70's and 80's - where quality didn't matter, and people didn't take the genre seriously. Or at least - making a good game into a good movie very seriously.

Personally, next to SMB and the SF movie, I kindly enjoyed Tomb Raider, and only the first Resident Evil movie. RE1 may have been far from the plot, but at least it went down with dignity. This movie... like anything by Uwe Boll, should be banished from all eternity. Maybe Uwe Boll with it too.

review_title: House of the Dud, more like it
review_detailed_main:
There isn't a single appealing characteristic present in House of the Dead. From the dull, suspense-dispensing opening to the ripped-off ending, this movie failed to entertain in any way whatsoever.

Jonathan Cherry apparently is shaping up to be the poor man's version of Bruce Campbell, only without the acting talent. His character Rudy spends much of the movie in a mopy fit, failing to do anything heroic, and even watching other characters die while he stands off to the side.

Emoional moments fail to work, mostly due to the actors, but also due to the script. Mark Altman and Dave Parker have xeroxed pages from other movies, threw in a few zombie references, and went clubbing for the rest of the day. Much of the dialogue is grating ("Matt? Matt? Matt? Is that you Matt? Matt? Is that you Matt? Matt?"...continue that for several more hours.)

In the commercials, the special effects are the most appealing element...great 360-degree shots while fighting. But in the actually movie, the editing around the shots is incoherent...Karma e.g., is holding one gun in a regular shot, then two guns in a static 360. Clips from the actual video game first are used as an entertaining breakaway between scenes, but are used distractingly during fight scenes. The lousy game over sequences used for certain characters is atrocious.

Don't waste your money...

You know, it kept my attention. I was younger, maybe not too wise as to the pitfalls of Uwe Boll movies. I assumed that it would be a decent adaptation of House of the Dead; but found that it was nothing like the video game. I laughed so much during this movie, it was entertainingly bad. I still have it somewhere in my DVD collection, and if I ever need something to remind me that whatever I've written - nothing could be as bad as the dialog in that movie. I have a fondness for bad horror movies, I absolutely love some of them, and loathe others. Trying to approach a movie like this with the sensibilities of a seasoned critic will not work. Just sit back and accept that what you are about to see is not supposed to be in any way a 'good movie' just entertaining.

review_title: A horrible movie that keeps you watching for all the wrong reasons.
review_detailed_main: House of the Dead" is one of the most challenging movies to rate, primarily because it balances its status as one of the worst films ever made with an undeniable, albeit unintentional, level of entertainment. The movie revolves around a nonsensical plot that serves mainly as a vehicle for teenagers and other characters to battle zombies and monsters on a remote island during a rave party. Despite its shortcomings, the film offers some engaging action scenes with plenty of shootouts and fights against zombies and other creatures. The makeup and costume design of the monsters and zombies are commendable, given the overall quality of the film. The acting and dialogue are notoriously poor, but this aligns with the similarly questionable voice acting and dialogue from the video game it is based on. The film's pacing is quick and keeps the viewer engaged, even though much of the plot remains bewildering. A subplot involving an old pirate and the release of a virus on the island adds to the chaotic nature of the story. While "House of the Dead" has received harsh reviews and is often considered one of the worst movies, it carries a certain charm for those who appreciate B-movie madness and are aware of the film's context. Watching it with an understanding of its reputation and taking it for what it is-an absurd, action-packed zombie flick-can make the experience surprisingly enjoyable.

I have seen pictures of people being brutally slain. I have read exerpts from the Book of Satan (the bible of Satanists...it was a school project, don't judge me) but I had never been afraid of humanity until this very moment. I watched House of the Dead for the second time tonight, mainly as a science experiment to see if it would drive my friend insane. It is, by far, the second worst movie ever made. I want you to understand my full meaning here. I've seen "Manos: Hands of Fate," I have seen "Phantom From 10,000 Leagues" and all of the 60s horror that can be shoved into a DVD player. I have even watched basic cable. Nothing could prepare me for Uwe Boll's defecation upon the genre of Video Game movies. This film, if the term applies since it appears to have been shot on the record function of a cell phone, breaks every rule of cinema. It has the worst acting of its time, and less horror than the average school lunch. I admit that I am biased, as I have also seen "Alone in the Dark" and have since given up religion or the thought of ever letting children enter this world with my genes. Uwe Boll also gets the credit (read: blame) for that one. If you have rented this film, or any Uwe Boll monstrosity, then do yourself a favor and drop the disc in the microwave. In fact, burn down the aisle in the video store where you rented it from. The taint of this film will forever stain you, but you can save others. That's all that's left for me. i have lost my soul because of this bastardization of the visual art. Pray for me.

AK

There are actually two kinds of game-adaptation movies: good ones, like Resident Evil, for example, and bad ones, like... like House of the Dead. However, this was not simply a bad movie: it was more like strange, stupid, pointless, AND bad. Oh, and let's not forget dumb - from all angles.

First of all, the story... let's see. A few kids are running up and down, chased by zombies, and eventually getting caught only to die a completely meaningless and unnecessary death. And this is not a plot summary, this is the whole story! I imagine the screenplay didn't have much more details than this. Then, the acting. Now that was funny... except for Jurgen Prochnow the actors were young "talents", but they didn't show much, mostly ran around screaming or shooting, before ending up dead. Fortunately the characters had no details and dimensions at all, so I didn't feel sorry for them when all of a sudden they died the most stupid way they could (one moment they were fighting like combat marines, the next they were zombie food, like if the director decided it was their turn to sacrifice themselves for nothing).

Other than those, there were a few remarkable effects in the movie I can't help mentioning. Before anyone starts to guess how much it resembled the game, I tell you: a hundred and ten per cent. First of all, there were scenes cut out directly from the arcade version of the game and placed into the movie one-in-one. This means you see the kids shooting, then for a sec you get a shooting scene from the game, then you see the kids again. There were plenty of such 'tricks' here and there - how very original, artistic, and incredibly DUMB of the director... Otherwise, fights were exactly the same as in the game, but seeing it in an arcade is more entertaining than in a movie. Imagine kids with huge guns, totally unaware of their lives being at stake or their friends getting killed time after time, shooting at countless zombies swarming around them (really, there were lots of scenes where you saw one of the "heroes" in slow-motion, shooting at a zombie running at him, while there were dozens of other monsters just running around, clearly without any intention to attack). Then, throw in a few bullett time effects (or something remotely alike), where there is your hero shooting/kicking/grinning, and the camera goes around him like in the player selection of any prestigeous arcade game. This looks good in the one-millionth episode of the Mortal Kombat series, but come on, are we doing a movie here or what? Dumb again.

Finally, a few words about the genre... just to see clearly. Horror... there was a significant amount of blood for sure, but the zombies looked more like old men and women, and seeing them chewing on the characters was laughable at most. Thriller - why so? I was not afraid a bit, only astonished by all this movie had to give. Mystery, now that's true: in the last 10 minutes or so, the remaining heroes uncovered an old legend connected to the zombies, which, however, didn't play any role at all in the plot. It just... WAS. And, to say the least, it was DUMB. Action? I give you that. There was plenty of it, from all kinds: all-out, frontal, gunpowder-smelling, sweaty, bullett-timey, arcade action. Dumb and pointless, that's true, but action

indeed.

What else should I say? I would recommend this movie to any who wants a good laugh at a stupid zombie flick with poor acting and no story. Otherwise - you may as well skip it and see a real horror movie.

No secret: 1 of 10

review_title: If you want respect as an actor, don't pick scripts like these!
review_detailed_main:
I usually try to be professional and constructive when I criticize movies, but my GOD!!! This was THE worst movie I have ever seen. Bad acting, bad effects, bad script, bad everything!

The plot follows a group of teen cliche's on their way to a rave (that takes place in broad daylight) at a remote island. However, when the group arrives, all they find is an empty dance floor and bloody clothes. Determined to find out what happened to the rest of the party-goers, the clan set's off on a mission through a zombie-infested forest. During this crusade, they are aided by a police chick and a sea captain that just happens to have the right number of weapons to give to each of the kids. They also meet up with Jonathan Cherry and some other survivors. Basically the rest of the movie is a collection of poorly directed action sequences including a far too long shootout outside of the "house of the dead." This fight came complete with cheesy Hollywood violence, redundant clips from the HOTD video game, and sloppy matrix-esque camera rotations. One of the character's even volunteers to sacrifice himself to save the others. Why? Not because he was noble and brave, but because part of his face got scarred by acid a zombie spat on him after he continued to beat the creature long after it had been disabled! I'm supposed to feel sorry for this guy?!?

To sum it all up, there is absolutely no point in seeing this movie unless you want to see for yourself just how terrible it is. The theater I was in was more dead than the zombies on the screen, and I'm sure the money I wasted seeing this piece of sh*t could easily cover the costs it took to make it. GRADE: F

review_title: Uwe Boll should have the camera ripped from his hands
review_detailed_main: Where do I begin with this one? How can I even explain how this ended up in my movie library? Let me just say this: this movie is bad. Not bad as in a bad mother  bad as in this movie stinks to high heaven and everyone involved in the making of it should leave the movie business right now. This is the type of movie that you can spend hours picking apart and pointing out all the little stupidities in it, but why bother? It's just another stupid adaptation of a video game, complete with cheesy scene transitions that cop footage from the game itself. Yes, you heard me right  they actually worked in footage from the video game as the scene transitions in some useless attempt to do something "artistic" when the truly correct and humane thing to do would have been to abandon the entire misbegotten and brainless project at the bottom of the deepest garbage can they could find. It's just another group of incredibly stupid and obnoxious teenagers who then transform into even more stupid and obnoxious martial arts/firearms masters who shoot endless streams of bullets and engage in truly ridiculous Matrix"-type fight scenes that go on FOREVER. Next time you're at your local DVD retailer, tick them off by asking how many unsold copies of this thing they got stuck with.

I've seen some bad movies before, but sweet mother of god...that's 90 minutes of my life i'll never get back.

I'd heard that this movie was bad, but being a game-movie enthusiast, I just had to give it a try.

Quite possibly one of the worst mistakes i've ever made...camera was bad, acting was bad, and the whole bit with splicing in clips from the actual game was just plain atrocious.

I think this is one of those really rare cases where the sequel(HOTD2) was actually better than the first.

Even if you hated this one, I would try the sequel, because at least that one is bearable--and has Emanuel (i don't remember how to spell her last name)pronounced Vo-jay

review_title: It is really as bad as they say
review_detailed_main:
I heard this movie sucks. I also saw that it is in IMDb's bottom 100 list. But I know that being bad is some-kind-of merit too and I'm interested in movies based on games so I rented this.

Movie starts promisingly with calm and cool narrator voice who tells about his friends. In this point dialog is funny and clever but immediately when the narrator stops there starts simple and clumsy dialog. I wrote that kind of dialog when I was six years old. Actors have no energy in their performances expect with that raincoat man but either his character or his acting is annoying.

Script has no surprises and plot is nearly invisible. They just go to some mysterious rave party in some mysterious island (Who arraigned that anyway?) and start to slaughter zombies when they attack. Characters reactions are unbelievable (I would mourn more if my friend became eaten by zombies) and their weapon skills are unrealistically good. I'm pretty sure that if they are first timers they can't shoot that well (or swing a sword on that matter) but how should I know since I haven't used any weapon in my life.

Uwe Boll tries to differ from gray director mass but any directing solution doesn't work. The worst mistake is adding parts from House of the Dead games in middle of action scenes. They cut them too much and make it feel like a video game even though it should feel like a movie. Action scenes are horrible anyway because there is added many cool camera angles which make it messy. Some times camera is just way too close. Also that rap music is bad and makes it feel like a comedy.

In summary this movie is worse than Battlefield Earth. Even that cool narrator changes energy-less and rushing in the end. Two funny jokes are not enough to save this. This film will be remembered as a true classic but from wrong reasons.

Before you completely disregard my review of Uwe Boll's House of the Dead, I only gave it a 10 because it was that entertaining to me. To me this movie wasn't supposed to be scary. In fact I place this movie in the genre of comedies. That's all that this movie was to me, a comedy. For people reading reviews, trying to figure out if this movie is worth it; I say hell no. I wouldn't pay 10 dollars to see it at a theatre, and I wouldn't pay 5 dollars to rent it. However I would pay 5 bucks to own it. Why? Every time I watch this movie I laugh.

I recommend this movie to anyone who watches movies as a form of entertainment, not an art form. When I watch a movie, I watch a movie to entertain me, and House of the Dead did just that.

Honestly what did most of you expect, the movie was based off a shitty video game.
