review_title: This makes MANOS look like HAMLET
review_detailed_main: I believe I wrote a review of this puppy when it first came out, under another name. Now that I have seen it as part of a Halloween package on Sci-Fi Channel, I felt compelled to write a new review under my current nom de plume. I honestly thought HOUSE might look better on a commercial channel, with cuts and lots of commercials. Wrong. HOUSE remains among the worst films ever made, right up there with AX EM, the worst movie ever made. A group of 20-somethings hit an island for a rave, only to find the island overrun by zombies. Along the way, they run into a cop and a couple of others who have survived the onslaught so far. The zombies are played by a group of extras who reminded me of the zombies in some of the Italian-made zombie cheapies. Little or no makeup, little or no direction. The 20-somethings are mostly nonactors as well. The shootings are done up video game-style (no surprise there). Nothing really happens. And we are quickly lulled to sleep. Jurgen Prochnow plays a cigar-chomping boat captain. He fails to act as well. Avoid this!

review_title: The lost 90 minutes, which i shall never get back

review_detailed_main:
Oh, House of the Dead (2003), what a masterpiece of cinematic disaster! It's like the filmmakers took a crash course in how not to make a horror movie. The plot, if you can even call it that, feels like it was written by a group of drunk zombies stumbling through a graveyard. It's so convoluted that even the characters look confused, and trust me, their acting skills are about as sharp as a spoon. You'll find yourself rooting for the zombies because they're the only ones showing any signs of life in this snooze-fest.

And let's talk about the special effects, shall we? I haven't seen CGI this outdated since my old flip phone. The zombies are about as terrifying as a puppy in a Halloween costume, and the action scenes are so poorly choreographed that I had to double-check if I accidentally stumbled into a high school drama club rehearsal. House of the Dead is so bad that even Uwe Boll probably disowns it in his list of cinematic atrocities. If you're looking for a good time, stay far, far away from this undead trainwreck of a movie.

Watched most of the way through this on TV, but switched channels before it ended. Some movies are so bad they are hilarious but this isn't. The plot doesn't make much sense but is not bad enough to be funny.

If it had all amateur actors it might be watchable, but this movie includes some otherwise good actors giving poor performances. Could have been a good movie or video game but the attempt to blend movie/video only hamstrung everyone.

Guaranteed channel-switcher. If you want to see people stuck on an island why not switch over to old Gilligan's Island reruns? They are better than this.

review_title: It's crap but a fun piece of trash.
review_detailed_main:
A group of College Kids (Jonathan Cherry, Ona Grauer, William Sanderson, Tyron Leitso, Enuka Okuma, Kira Clavell & Sonya Solomaa) just wants to party during their spring break. They are invited to a rave in a island outside from Seattle. Once they arrived... it's completely deserted but soon they find out, they are not alone. When a group of bloodthirsty zombies comes to kill or eat them alive. Now these group of kids along with a boat captain (Jurgen Prochnow) and a marine police officer (Ellie Cornell) battle the undead to stay alive.

Directed by Uwe Boll (Alone in the Dark, BloodRayne, Postal) made an another instant Camp Classic film with plenty of ridiculous humour, first class bad acting but at least... it has some exciting action sequences and good make-up effects. This is one of Boll's most entertaining film along with "Dungenon Siege". Prochnow gives the film's best performance and he seems to be having some fun in the movie but he was unhappy with the script changes during production. Cult B-Movie Actor:Clint Howard appears in a small role as the skipper. This film was an small success in theaters but find itself instead cult audiences on DVD, for those who enjoyed bad movies.

DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer and an strong DTS 5.1 Surround Sound (Also in Dolby Digital 5.1). DVD includes two entertaining commentary tracks by the filmmakers. Commentary one is by the director, crew members and actor:Sanderson. The Second Commentary by the Executive Producer/Story/Co-Screenwriter:Mark A. Altman is the most enjoyable to listen. DVD also includes Deleted Scenes, Two Featurettes and more. "House of the Dead" is a enjoyable bad movie but there's one thing... i truly hated in this feature is Boll's use of showing video game footage every couple of minutes or so. It relies too heavily on reminding viewers, we are watching an live-action video game. Since this feature was shot on Super 35, which it was seen in theaters in the 2.35:1 aspect ratio. Probably in the Uwe Boll's new re-cut of "House of the Dead:Funny Version" will might see it in the original 2.35:1 format. Which it's coming out soon on DVD. If you love bad film-making, don't miss this. (*** 1/2 out of *****).

I am not sure how this guy gets to make films. Every film he makes is just a bunch of "good looking" young people horrible miscast in a sequence of special effects scenes stolen from other films. I can not think of a single feature of this film which validates it's existence. Possibly the most hideous part of this film was the slow rotating shots of the cast members when they did.. well.. anything. Oh and the fact that they all knew how to use weapons which they would have, most likely, never seen in their life. To me this kind of film damages genres such as horror and science fiction and gives fuel to the critics of science fiction in general. There has to be some way we can stop this guy making movies.. please let there be!!!

review_title: An insult to horror movie fans (and to viewers in general)
review_detailed_main:
I like House of the Dead (VG). It has not a brilliant story like metal gear for example, but I spent hours playing (and wasting money on) it.

When I saw this title, I decided to give it a try. The game story was interesting enough and, after all, there were zombies and creepy creatures on it!! I must admit I didn't expect this movie to be outstanding, but neither did I expect to be like this. Sometimes we complaint about movies without being objective, because we didn't like this or that, and other viewers can think different. This is the one movie where this rule doesn't apply. The movie sucks, it has no plot (even the game had a better plot, and you were shooting things 99% of the time), the jokes are not funny, the actors seem retarded, but the worst is that for the first time in my life this movie gave me the impression that the director was insulting me and my intelligence (I don't know how to explain it in other way). It seems like the guy is laughing his ass off in front of all the fans of the game (if any) and all the people who paid something to see his "work".

Don't get me wrong, I'm a fan of horror movies, and I'm accustomed to bad movies (in fact there are few good horror movies out there) but this one crosses the line of RESPECT towards the viewer. Other directors at least tried to do something right, this man tried to do everything wrong and insulting, and I must admit he excelled at it.

Many of you might guess (correctly) that English is not my home language, and I apologize for the mistakes, but Im taking the burden so at least one person can avoid wasting money and (especially) time on this (spanish) "mierda" :).

review_title: THE worst movie I've ever had the displeasure of seeing
review_detailed_main: Even after seeing hundreds of horror movies since I was first allowed to watch them in the early 70's, I have never seen a movie as bad as this one. Not only is the plot a rehash of every other horror movie - although it was claimed to be based on the very popular video game - but the directing and editing of this piece of dreg are what drive this movie to an average rating of around 2 (I'm actually surprised it's that high.) The interlacing of video game zombie shots, the almost never-ending fight sequence in the cemetery, the "Matrix" effects, and so on, also put this movie way, way over the edge. I actually greatly enjoy those "so-bad-they're-good" movies, but this is by far no where near that level. Luckily, I had rented this waste of media instead of buying it because I would have used it to pick up my dog's sh!t out in the back yard. 'Nough said about this crappy movie!

There isn't an easy way to explain the movie's plot... or lack there of... the short summary has something to do with a pirate captain seeking revenge and somehow he gains the ability to raise the dead. Then comes these teenagers. The women lose their shirt at any opportune time possible, even times that really aren't opportune at all. Each protagonist spends their time doing all the wrong things and mindlessly delving into this meaningless story that has nothing to do with any of them.

In the simplest summary I can make for this movie, it is simply zombies, pirates, explosions, and boobs. If that's enough to make you feel sufficient with a movie then you should definitely reevaluate your idea of a good movie viewing experience.

review_title: I'm sure you something better to do than watch this
One of the three worst horror movies ever made!
review_detailed_main: What a perfectly good waste of film, good locations, sets and make-up effects. Horrible story/plot, even worse dialogue and acting. There's no words describing this garbage of a movie. Good thing that my roommate rented it and I wasted no money in watching that crap. The only thing I wasted was an hour and a half of my life. If you've had the displeasure of seeing the equally horrible "Dead Hate The Living," written and directed by the same imbecile that wrote "House Of The Dead," you'll see the obvious similarities with the horribly-written dialogue. Believe all of the reviews, it really IS that bad. Still, "FearDotCom" is worse, but this steaming pile of donkey sh#t is very close behind it. Definitely one of the worst three horror movies ever made. The other two being "FearDotCom" and "The Woodchipper Massacre."

review_title: Worst zombie movie ever... The very bottom of the barrel
review_detailed_main: Stupidest movie I ever seen and believe me, I've seen a lot of bad movies. This isn't even a bad movie that's funny because it's bad, it bad plain and simple (even painful to watch really). The story is very basic and there is no such thing as suspense or unexpected events it isn't even scary. I particuliarly couldn't believe the scene where the teens go back to some sort of abandoned house on the island and they start to kill the zombies... the scene is on slow motion with cheap matrix like effects and it goes on for at least 5 long, very long minutes. This movie was apparently based on a video game (I don't know the title)and the producers keep flashing in-game footage throughout the film. If you're a Romero fan, avoid at all cost. If you're a stupid teen who wants to see gore and a few pairs of boobs... well I don't care. I sincerelly can't believe I paid to rent this...

review_title: Worst movie until the son of the mask
review_detailed_main: This is the lamest excuse for a movie... Heck, I don't even think I could call it a movie because more than 60% of this movie contained scenes from the game.... Don't see this steaming pile of dookie. The zombie fight scenes were never really shown because every time something got blasted, it showed something from the game, most likely a zombie scratch on the screen. Any time a character in the movie died it would show a rotation of that character and I think it said game over, I can't remember. It was one of those movies that I rented where I went to the kitchen and made a sandwich, then I talked on the phone, then I drove to the corner store for some cigars, and I never pushed pause once.
Amazing camerawork, masks, acting and directing by Uwe Boll.

review_title: Uwe Boll should be in jail after this.
review_detailed_main: If you want to see what a cinematic piece of dog barf looks like, go see House of the Dead, otherwise do yourself a favor and play the video game, it's far more entertaining. House of the Dead If movies were cars, House of the Dead would be the back-firing K-car with the scrapyard windshield and a rag for a gas cap. It's a patchwork of poor acting, poor editing and even poorer writing. It's a video game adaptation in every sense and, in case you forgot, the filmmakers remind you by flash cutting scenes from the actual video game during the film! It's only saving grace was the action sequence three quarters into the film that has some fun special effects  it's so bad it barely falls into the so-bad-it's-good category. A band of idiots and a take-no-prisoners go-go dancer (?) end up on Isla del Muerte for the rave of the year only to get eaten by the "re-animated homo sapient" of a centuries old priest who was banished to the island from Spain for creating a death-cheating serum. If you want to see what a cinematic piece of dog barf looks like, go see House of the Dead, otherwise do yourself a favor and play the video game, it's far more entertaining.

But it's not as bad as I've heard some people make it out. Some people claim that the entire film, from start to finish, is one big turd. That's not quite so. There are some nice shots and... well, Jürgen Prochnow is in it. But that's it.

Apparently, there is a large rave on a big island in the middle of nowhere and a group of teens want to get to it. So they pay a strange fisherman (Prochnow) to get them there. When they arrive, they realize (well, at least one of them does) that something is out of place. That's right, something is out of place. The entire rave is empty, yet only one of the characters seem bothered by this.

Soon they are attacked by zombies and team up with other people to survive this hellish night. Or something like that.

Why did I watch this film? Because I wanted some zombie action. I wanted to see some people be bitten, scream and turn into zombies. To bad the zombies in this film are nothing like ordinary zombies. Forget anything you think you know about zombies. These guys are not tough. They're pushovers. Shoot them anywhere, and they go down. Also, they're fast. And they fight, with weapons and karate moves! As a matter of fact, these zombies are like ordinary humans except that they don't talk. It could have been any action movie out there, but just replaced the bad guys wardrobe with lots of rotting flesh.

The dialog is some of the worst I've ever heard. It's so ridiculous, and when coming out of these actor's mouths I can't help but to smile. It's really stupid, and laughable. But the problem with this film is that it's very dull. It's no "Plan 9 from Outer Space" where you can sit back and enjoy the lack of brains. It's just dull. The plot, the characters, the monsters. Everything! There's a lot of strange things going on as well. For example, there's a ten minute long action scene with people just shooting zombies in "cool" ways. Sure, could have worked for a minute or two. But for TEN MINUTES?! You'll be tempted to fast forward through that, trust me. Especially since it's very stupid. A bunch of rave teens suddenly turn into Neo, Trinity and Morpheus and karate kick, bullet-time jump and blast their way through hordes of zombies. And I mean, hordes! There must have been at least a hundred zombies or so killed in that sequence alone, if not more! Between scenes, there's shots from the game. It makes no sense, but they are there. Suddenly, computer graphics (from the game) pop up on the screen and you wonder what the hell is going on. Don't worry, it's just a scene transition.

One of the most boring films I've ever seen, and even so there's always something happening. That's when you know there's something wrong. But in all fairness, I HAVE seen worse films. There are a couple of stylished shots that look cool and since you walk in with low expectations you probably won't be that disappointed.

I give it a three. It's bad, it's not worth watching, but I've seen worse.

review_title: A plot in the search of a story with decent FX
review_detailed_main:
"a group of teens go to an island for a rave" I can destroy this one quickly.. these people haven't been teens, to be generous, in 5 years. A rave? Geez, I've seen better raves at the mall on kiddie night.. THIS RAVE HAS CORPORATE SPONSORS! Enough of that.. Uwe Boll, if that is his real name (I know I wouldn't put my real name on this slice of dreck) should hide his face in shame. What should have been a decent man eating zombie movie has become, and I say this sincerely, potboiler. The characters are cliché, the villains are cliché, and the supporting cast is cliché. The FX were pretty decent, but EVEN THE FREAKING STUNTS WERE Cliché!!! They looked like something out of "The A Team".

Uwe Boll tries to be the Ang Lee of the American cinema. He uses a HELL OF A LOT of those freeze frame tricks, and they detract from the movie, in my opinion. Too much eye candy causes brain decay, Uwe! Too much time expansion, I mean, come on, 5 to 7 minutes to cross 50 yards, even with zombies is a BIT MUCH! I didn't time it the first time, and I can't bring myself to watch it again to get the correct time. The first time felt like am eternity. I haven't seen anything this bad in years, and I can't remember last time I did, even stretching my considerable mental facilities to their fullest! I could have done better with a Betacam and a minimum editing facility, as long as I had a decent FX house behind me. The zombies were fairly decent, if, you guessed it, cliché. If you want a real zombie movie with a halfway decent plot and story, don't waste your time on this pile of recycled dreck, watch one of the Romero movies, or Sam Raimi's "Evil Dead" movies, or even one of the "Return Of The Living Dead" movies (except 4 or 5)

*** LEAVE THIS ON THE SHELVES AT THE VIDEO STORE *** Even the sex scenes were cliché, and about as sexy as watching octogenarians go at it.

My humble opinion

Bill

review_title: I am ashamed. I cared about one of the characters.
review_detailed_main:
Of course, only the kick-ass captain played by the only competent actor IN this abomination, but still, it's Uwe Boll and my heart fills with shame.

The idea is actually not that dreadful, but I feel I must mention that the idea may be serviceable, the execution of it nothing less than a train wreck created by two nuclear warhead transports right next to Chernobyl.

What hallucinogens does Uwe Boll take I wonder, before he decides to make these films, and what must he take when they are done and he passes them for release? The Characters were 2-d at best (apart from the captain who I wanted to live so badly just so SOME good could come out of this thing) and the dialogue must have been written by someone who had only a vague idea of what human speech was and tried to dictate to a person who only spoke a foreign language. And was deaf.

The fighting was terribly done and I'm sorry but the black girls wrists would have been snapped clean away if she was REALLY firing a desert Eagle with each hand.

review_title: Rubbish but the action is okayish
A film of epic proportions, deep and poetic.
Um, can anybody say "28 Days Later"?
review_detailed_main: This movie "House of the Dead" is just a bad zombie movie attempt at "28 Days Later". I saw "28D" this summer and it was excellent. The directors did such an excellent job on the cinematography and the plot was great. The movie didn't needed a DMX single to sell the trailer. The visual alone was intruiging. "House of the Dead" sucks. Don't go see it. Rent instead "28 Days Later" when it comes out on video & DVD later in October!

House of the Dead was dead before the ink dried on th last page of the script. It is by far one of the worst films I have ever seen. Now, saying that, I gave the film a three. Uwe Boll may not be a great director, but he doesn't bend in his artist integrity. He makes films like he wants, so there could be so many negative comments about this film, and it wouldn't matter. Boll is a good figure to look at if you are an aspiring filmmaker. This film can be used as a example in low budget film-making. How to or how not to do is up to you. All other things aside, this is a horrible attempt at a zombie flick, and the fact that it is based on a video game, doesn't help it either. Johnathan Cherry and Jurgen Prochnow are the only "actors" here, as the rest of the cast should have been buried with this film in a movie vault far, far away. There are low camera angles that reveal how bad the special effects are. There is one cool effect, but a few good things, can't save this loser. Watch Romero's stuff, and leave this trash alone.

review_title: Is Uwe Boll the Grim Reaper of Video Game-Based Movies?
review_detailed_main: Okay, I seen terrible movies in my life, but I just about puked watching this movie and I'm not referring to the gore, I'm talking about how terrible this movie was, if anyone found this movie scary, you must be so paranoid, even your shadow scares you, splicing footage from the games isn't cool, this movie felt like someone's school project than a Hollywood film, if I $7 million dollars, I buy something else beside this movie, I mean, the action sequences were okay, but what's with the 360? They showing the characters in full view? if I want zombies killing people, I watch Dawn of the Dead or 28 Days Later than this, heck, Resident Evil was better, only good acting was the Captain, that's it! This is a Message to Uwe Boll: STOP MAKING MOVIES!!! 1 out of 10

review_title: Worst movie I have ever seen
review_detailed_main: I have seen some bad movies in my day but, this takes the cake. All those who have not seen this, I invite you to partake in this, just to know what a bad movie is. I won't give away too much but, when zombies who have been dead for decades are engaging in swordplay........I don't need to say more about that do I? I have noticed that someone rated this movie as a 10. It is because of people like that, that this movie doesn't get the true place in the bottom 100 movies on IMDb. It needs to be in the bottom 5 at least. I know that some of you will read this and say, "I know what a bad movie is, I don't need to see this to know", I say to you, look at this and then decide. They have many scenes where they show the video game where the movie came from during the movie. There are zombies that look like trees and then they stand up and start fighting. This movie was in the movie theatre, so it has to be in a different category than "Critters 4". Someone funded this film and they should be ashamed.

review_title: Run Run RUN... From this movie.
review_detailed_main:
Dear God, I havent even heard of the video game itself, but it looked interesting enough in the previews. However when I rented this abysmal film, I had no idea what I was getting into.

First - there's the plot itself. 5 People head out to an island to be a part of the hottest rave of the century (which by the way, looks like it would've sucked to begin with) only to find a handful of survivors and an island full of the undead. From here, survival becomes their only thought as they desperately try to escape the island. It's possible that this could have been successfully written despite most video game to movies being rather unsuccessful however this movie fails rather adeptly. Plot holes are large enough for an army of zombies to march through as issues such as how the virus is spread, how there seem to be more zombies than originally started on the island and many more are never addressed.

Second - there's the absolutely terrible acting. These people mustve just been hired out of a college acting class because they hardly bring across any of the emotions your supposed to feel. Along with this comes the special effects: overdone, repetitive and taken almost right out of the Matrix itself with no effort made to bring originality into the mix.

This movie, terribly done and a pain to watch, deserves nothing more than a 1 as it really isnt worth the 5 bucks to rent.

review_title: I didn't know they made movies this bad!

review_detailed_main: Honestly, this movie is by far the biggest stinker I've seen in years. Prior to this, I felt that Jeepers Creepers was the biggest let down in modern horror history, but this movie has really taken the cake. It has all the subtlety of a porn flick, the production value of a cheap porn flick, and all the plot of one too...minus the porn. Sure, it's got a nice high gore ratio, and several half decent splatter moments...but that doesn't make up for the rest of the deficits. For as much as they spent on this flick, there's just not a lot to praise...even the die hard monster movie watchers in the audience tonight were disappointed...and two of them talked through the damn thing, making me wish I had some way to silence THEM...and oy, the overuse of the clips from the video game. Sega should be ashamed. This is a genuine Turkey...makes Blood Freak look GOOD.

I watched this last night whilst playing on my PC. I actually started concentrating less on the game and more on this film as it went along, I even got my friend tuned in to watch it with me whilst communicating via a headset. The reason I've scored this a 2 is because its bloody comical. I don't actually know if it's supposed to be funny, but if it isn't it's that awful that it is anyway. Wait till you see the part where one of the shocking actors picks up the half eaten carcass of another shocking member of the cast and drags her in through the window... Both my friend and I were in absolute stitches.

Is no point going on and on about the actors, the set, the dialogue etc. Its a proper cheapo film, end of...How it made it to the big screen is totally beyond me, but if you want a really good laugh then get a couple of beers down you and watch this with a few mates. The film does have one saving grace and that's in the form of several half naked attractive girls... oof.

review_title: Well technically the score is a Zero but it won't go lower.
review_detailed_main:
Jonathan Cherry, Tyron Leitso, Clint Howard, Ona Grauer, Ellie Cornell, Will Sanderson. Directed by Uwe Boll.

Sorry for the mix-up, technically the score is a Zero but it won't go

any lower. An adaptation to the House of the dead video game, sound

familiar Resident Evil maybe. The whole movie had horrible acting,

story line and violence. The movie had too much camera movement, it

looked like Man on Fire. The camera was never still and it had

unnecessary spinning. I don't know what made me more sick the camera or

the movie itself. The movie enough said right. Zombies were not meant

to talk or sword fight! My final rating 0/10. A sad sad zombie film.

review_title: One of the Worst Movies of the 21st Century
Not too bad, his most memorable...
review_detailed_main: Truth be told, I did love this film. Believe it or not, this movie is very close to the game. Loads of zombies, loads of lead, loads of gore, bad story, bad acting, and a stupid final boss. Uwe Boll makes it all seem stylish because he realizes the strength of the game came from the game-play, and the oceans of gore. The video game scenes were weird, although I did enjoy the opening credits, and the way the camera circled around a character was pretty pointless. Yet it's corniness charmed me. Most importantly, the flow of the movie kept me going. A pure action flick with VERY stylized violence. There are some nice tidbits here and there, like when Castillo put his tongue into the girls ear. Very disturbing moment to say the least. I think he made a fun popcorn movie where people can make fun of it, but have a good time because of the movie itself. Also, I enjoyed the effects a lot, and was a fan of the zombie make-up/gore.

review_title: A horrible movie indeed, but fun to laugh at.
This movie is not worth your time or money
review_detailed_main:
I know very well that by giving this movie a 1 on the scale from 1 to 10, it increases the chance of making fans of bad movies watch it.

"House of the dead" is one of the most uninteresting, boring, horribly produced and acted movies that I have ever seen. A friend brought it last night and we were going to enjoy it. The joy ended as soon as the movie started. I am not going to give you any spoilers, but if you like zombie movies because you think they are hilarious, you will not find any of that kind of humour in here. It is just.. incredibly dull and boring. I am not going to comment on the actors *bites tongue*, as the producer mainly is to blame for this waste of time.

"House of the dead" is AWFUL, and I don't mean that in a GOOD way!

This was possibly the WORST film I have ever seen - and I've seen some total crap in my time (Video Dead, Children of the Dead, to name a couple of notably bad ones).

I'd tick the "contains spoiler" box, but let's be fair - the director/writer did all the spoiling already! Having watched this film I feel dirty - in the worst way. If anyone wanted to make legal history by trying a lawsuit against film makers who promise great stuff in their trailers, but then delivery utter trash, this would be the film. I don't think they could find enough money to cover the damages from the trauma I've experienced as a result of being subjected to this monumental steaming turd! 1 out of 10???? I don't think it even deserves that!!!!!

review_title: Fortunately... I didn't go to theaters to see this.
review_detailed_main: Where do I begin with such a disgrace? The movie is basically a piece of crap. Even Uwe Boll said that he just made this to make this for fun. Anyway, this movie is terrible. Anyone thinking about seeing this (hopefully no one) should turn away now. It was a waste of time for me. There's a ridiculous plot with some kids going to some party at some place. Then zombies show up. Great. I'm guessing it took three days to film this movie, because the acting in this is terrible, jumping from one emotion to the next, and where do they get these guns in this? It's terrible from beginning to finish, except for Clint Howard in the beginning and the name of the boat captain being called Captain Kirk. Uwe Boll even said he didn't care. If he doesn't, why should he think anyone else will?

Sometimes a film's reputation precedes it, but you decide to see for yourself just how bad it is. House Of The Dead is that sort of film. I knew going in that it would probably be of below average quality, but I had no idea just how ridiculous this movie would be. From the horrid acting to the ludicrous dialogue to the bad accents, I was ashamed for whoever was responsible for this movie. The ultimate camp effect was achieved by editing in frames from Sega's old video game upon which this film is based, it just looked that bad. I thought those bits were to be edited out due to initial negative reactions? At any rate, save your money and wait for the remake of Dawn Of The Dead if you're craving a zombie fix, there's nothing to see here.

This is about the worst movie I have ever seen. This movie does match the quality of such movies as "THEY" & "Cabin Fever", but even those had name actors where this one fell short. The "eye candy" of this movie looked to be a 50 woman with a bad face lift. (just an example of the quality). I would have rated this movie in the negative if possible. Ladies I have to tell you that the men were not bad to look at, but not much either. If you were planning on going to see this movie I would strongly recommend saving your money.

review_title: a video game adaptation so bad it's baffling
review_detailed_main:
A group of youngsters travel to a deserted island to attend a rave; however, a zombie outbreak occurs and they must survive the night.

More often than not video game movies are not great, even the better ones are just alright. However, the worst offender of the video game movie genre is Uwe Boll and his first American movie was an adaptation of the popular light gun game, House of the Dead.

While this isn't his worst movie, it insinuates everything wrong with an Uwe Boll movie. The script is badly written, the decisions characters make are dumb and the directing decisions are baffling.

There are several moments when clips from the video game are used as transitions or to intercut with action scenes. This is incredibly distracting and I'm aware it's an attempt to make it look and feel like a video game but it's a damn movie. Also, when characters die they use this 360-degree rotating shot which is another terrible gimmick.

I'll give the movie some credit though, it's so bad it's hilarious. It has lots of shooting action, gore, late nineties electronic music and Matrix-esque bullet time sequences, while simultaneously trying to make it look like a video game.

Uwe Boll continued to make other cinematic abominations such as Bloodrayne, Alone in the Dark, In the Name of the King, Far Cry, Postal and Rampage. Boll retired from filmmaking at the end of 2016, leaving behind a legacy of the worst video game adaptations imaginable.

review_title: Now this is a video game movie!!!
review_detailed_main:
House of the Dead (2003)is what Resident Evil should have been. A cheesy b-movie filled with bad dialog, bad actors and gory special effects. I can't express how much love I have for this flick. I thought the movie was going to be like Wrong Turn (yuk!) but boy was I wrong. How can you not love Clint Howard or the cigar chomping old salt of a captain Jurgen Prochow. Everything was perfect for this movie, the dialog (bad) the acting (wretched)the music (loud) and it had HEAD SHOTS!! The only thing that bothered me was that the rave was sponsored by "SEGA"?! I never heard of a corporate sponsored rave. Oh well. I bet the director had this on his mind when he made the movie (I have a lousy script, a low budget and some bad actors. Hell, I'll make one of the cheesiest b-movies ever based on a video game!). I have to say he succeeded.

Highly recommended!

review_title: Boll... put down the camera before you hurt... well, more of us
review_detailed_main: There are bad movies. There are guilty pleasures. There are movies that are so bad, they're good(and a select few that go beyond that, *back* to bad... thank you, Ghost World). But Uwe Boll's movies... this may be the first one I've watched, though I wouldn't exactly brag about having watched more than one, except maybe on account of having that high tolerance. Uwe Boll's movies... just saying it, sort of, you know, bad aftertaste. He seems to largely make movies based on video-games(at what point does "someone's gotta do it" become "... if he's our only option, I can do without it"?), and, while I can agree that that might not be the easiest kind to make(has there been a truly good one yet? They tend to range between "watchable" and... "not"), it would seem that Boll's are extraordinarily poor. The plot is... worse than it had to be. The acting is atrocious. The dialog is awful. The editing and cinematography both seem dead-set on turning the "film" into a music video, and the action... well, you might as well watch someone play the game(at times, it would be *more* entertaining to do so), better yet, play it yourself. The use of footage from the game, all... *32*?(!) of them... uh, yeah, Uwe? Don't. The music... eh. Language is loose, there is some nudity, and plenty of violence/gore. Attempts are made to recreate some of the recognizable images from the game, with reasonable success, I suppose. I recommend this to... fans of... Uwe...? No, that's not it... people looking for horror...? Hm... well, if you've got *nothing* to do for an hour and a half, if it's on or you've borrowed it(so there's no personal cost to you, money-wise), I guess there are worse things to be doing, if that does make for a terribly short list. 1/10

review_title: The worst junk in the horror history!
review_detailed_main: I give "House of the dead" vote 3/10 since this must be the worst movie I have seen in a long time. Jurgen is the only reason this movie get's a 3/10. All though the blond girl made it fun to watch, by being stupid, this was still not a very interesting movie to see. Some of the lines in "House of the dead" were to low for me and I have a sense of humor. I have seen most of the low budget horror movies since the 70s and not all of them are good, but this is worse than all the other movies together. How ever, Jurgen is still Jurgen, but I felt that what on earth was he thinking doing this movie? I read the user comment before seeing this movie and was surprised to see how right the guy was for once. According to the user comment, you would see people running through the woods, flashes of zombies and running people again. review_title: Video game action is taken to a new low.
review_detailed_main:
The Story: A group of college students from Seattle charter the fishing boat of Victor Kirk, a guns smuggler, to take them to an island where a big rave party is being held. But they arrive to find all the partygoers dead. After being attacked by zombies, they arm themselves with Kirk's weapons & take on the zombies in a massive battle.

Ever since the mid-1990s, there have been videogames featuring zombies, from "Resident Evil" to "House of the Dead". While "Resident Evil" was an intelligent & frequently scary example of survival horror, "House of the Dead" was just mindless FPS action, where the only goal was to kill as many zombies as you can. The zombies in the game are just an excuse to appeal to zombie fans in the same way that "Resident Evil" did (& did better). Both games have since been turned into feature films, along with sequels. While the film version of "Resident Evil" was a success, even if not an entirely good film, "House of the Dead" is a failure on all counts. The script, being written by fans of the game, is extremely poor - why is there a rave party held on a deserted island? The acting is negligible, although Jurgen Prochnow gives an enjoyable performance as the smuggler Captain Kirk (there are a couple of jokes about "Das Boot" and "Star Trek"). Clint Howard plays the bugged-out sailor in a bad way. While most zombie films are driven for outlandish gore effects, this one is driven for action film poses & is an excuse to showcase some silly 'bullet-time' scenes, as well as display some screenshots from the original game. Both are exercises in cinematic stupidity. That said, the action scenes are not too bad.

As I watched House of the Dead, I kept trying to remind myself that a "1" rating should REALLY be reserved for films that are not only poorly acted, poorly plotted, poorly written, poorly directed, poorly filmed, poorly edited, poorly scored, and so on...No, I said to myself, a "1" movie has to be actually incompetent, something like "Manos, Hands of Fate," which barely even qualifies as an actual movie.

Halfway through the movie, I gave up. It had to be a "1." Somehow, seeing that over 50% of IMDB reviewers agree with me has restored my faith in humanity.

What can be said about this miserable waste of time? The plot has holes you could throw a corpse through (why is the 'biggest rave of the year' on an inaccessible island? Why do the cops ride in one at a time instead of, say, bringing in backup? Or simply shooting the smuggler captain from the beginning? Where did this bunch of weakling coeds suddenly acquire sharpshooting skills and martial arts?). The acting is beyond bottom of the barrel -- your local high-school drama department could come up with more emotional delivery of lines. Even the visuals, which should be the saving grace of this movie, manage to leech all possible tension or energy from each shot (we keep seeing dozens of zombies carefully 'sneaking' behind our heroes, for instance...why aren't they gnawing on their vitals?)

There are children starving in the world, and these useless people decided that it would be better to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on this movie instead...and then had the gall to send it into theatres. Everyone involved in the production of this film should serve jail time. F-.

review_title: Crap, crap, and MEGA crap... Who else has done that?
review_detailed_main:
Okay, this is going to be long, but please bear with me. Now, I'm not going to spoil this movie for anybody who might not have seen it, but I'll just give you a little NON-SPOILING teaser-like thing. Just to give you context. IT'S HORRIBLE!!! This is how the movie was made: The director grabbed every bad movie that was ever made by human being, all of the worst dialogue and shoved it into a shotgun. Then the director pulled the trigger and then picked up the pieces and placed them all nicely on a table and then grabbed a bazooka and blew up what was left of the movies/screenplays. But somehow a few pieces managed to stay intact. So he sent the writer to pick up all the pieces of the movie and tried to make a script out of it (TRIED) and failed miserably. He thought he was making a script, but nothing seemed right. But he didn't care. He just handed that to the actors and they TRIED to read it, but it was so confusing and stuff that they thought it was a combination of Peruvian/Russian/Japanese and Elvish (from Lord of the Rings) Obviously, one language is hard enough to learn and one of these languages shouldn't even be known by the average Joe and plain Jane. But the actors didn't care. They TRIED to read but got nothing and then lost the scripts an eighth of the way through shooting.

Then the actors go to the director for... well... DIRECTION!!! (an amazing unheard concept. I mean, whoever heard of a director giving directions? Hmm) Well, he finally decided to help. But this guy is a big fat guy and he forgot what movie he was making. So trying to make himself sound like he still knew what he was doing, he just kept saying stuff like, "okay and then... this person shows up... and then... you die... No the zombie won't kill you. It's part of the drama. Just lie there and pretend to die. yeah, good. Perfect." but in the end, he realized that this wasn't helping and... well, actually, he did something really smart. As in, seriously, this was pretty cool. No other director could have pulled it off. (ie: Spielberg, Lucas, Jackson) The director went to get a lobotomy.

Then he came back and WITH A PSYCHIC TRANSLATOR. Interesting enough, this psychic translator believed that he could read the minds of vegetables. (Which doesn't make sense because the part of their mind that allows thought is gone) But he couldn't really. So the actors turned to them for help and asked the translator what the director was thinking. But he couldn't understand anything. (Amazing) He was reading his OWN mind, but he still didn't get it. He thought he was hearing a combination of German/Russian and a form of Slavic. And the best part is, this psychic translator is a fat little Egyptian kid with a twinky in his mouth. And he telling the actors what he thinks the director is saying but he doesn't speak English. But the actors (smart as they are) think that they know what he's saying a begin improvising the whole damn movie.

That's pretty much what you've got. My advise to you, see it if you must. You will not like it, and if you do, tell me why. I haven't the slightest idea how you can like this movie. You can enjoy it maybe, but not like it.

(By the way, I have nothing against Egyptians. I think they are a highly underrated people. I am not trying to insult anyone who is Egyptian or a vegetable. Even if you were involved with House of the Dead.) So all in all, bad movie, save your time, not worth it unless you want to make fun of it. -10/10. (yeah, it's that good.)

review_title: brilliant abstract rendering of Dostoyevsky's novel
review_detailed_main: When I heard there was going to be a film of Fyodor Dostoyevsky's fictionalised prison memoir The House of the Dead set in the present day, I was skeptical. However, whilst it may not be true to the letter of the novel, it retains its spirit. The prison is an island, and the prisoners a group of American teenagers. Their inner demons have been literalised as zombies which they must defeat in order to survive their ordeal. If Dostoyevsky - who IMDb has curiously not given story credit, by the way - were alive today, I'm sure he'd greatly approve of this imaginative adaptation. It's superior to the also excellent Idiocracy (The Idiot), but perhaps not quite as good as Crime and Punishment in Suburbia.

I'll say this about Uwe Boll: You know what you're getting - and it's a shitload of crap. He's got to be the only "director" in the world who manages to get everything wrong.

The movie in short: Group of teens goes to an island to rave, but are attacked by... well, supposedly zombies. Not even the trees look convincing, though. We get crap acting in combination with crap make-up, in crap scenery, accompanied by a crap score and based on a crap screen-play. It looks like a beginners class of improv, so it wasn't a big surprise to find that the word "choreography" wasn't mentioned once in the credits.

"House of the Dead" does however teach the following valuable lessons:









Remember: Pain is only momentary, fatal blows to major arteries do not bleed (unless you're a corpse), and a hole through the heart is not a valid reason to stop moving... - IF you're a living human, that is. If you're a re-animated, undead corpse, a kick to the back will however knock, and keep, you down.

And all those guns they had! It looked like they were ready to fight the dead! Incredible!!! Worst is a nice word for this movie. 1 is very big grade for this movie. So don't watch it! Don't lose a hour and a half of your life with it!

What was this atrocious movie unleashed by Sci-Fi channel as I turned on the TV? All the horror movie clichés were there: partying teens, killer zombies, mindless dialog, meandering script, screaming, carnage, etc. As the movie got even worse, a little subtitle in the corner of the screen announced the grim truth, "Now: House of the Dead." I had heard this was awful; but the fullest extent of its awfulness had yet to assault me.

From out of nowhere, the teens-in-peril find a cache of guns and ammo, and suddenly they act like Rambo on steroids, blasting ghouls by the hundreds. In the ensuing battle, those worn-out "Matrix" rip-off shots were used everywhere: the freeze-frame 360 degree "virtual reality" spin around a character, the slow-mo close-ups of bullets approaching their target, the projectile path illustrated in dizzying pans, etc.

To my shock and disbelief, some idiot was inserting quick cuts from the actual video-game. Once would have been pointless and irritating enough, but this insane technique was incessantly crammed down your throat until you felt ill.

The director was not even trying to make a movie, just a blast fest rehash of a video game. And a rotten effort of duplicating the game, at that. I did not vote a "1" on this because I laughed a few times at the ineptitude, but even there, it just barely achieved the so-bad-it's-funny status.

If you have a strong tolerance for bad movies in an MST3K sort of way, watch with friends, and hoot at it. That's the only way to actually enjoy this.

review_title: "House of the Dead" is honestly the worst of the worst... It has my vote for 'Worst Movie Ever"...
review_detailed_main:
In reviews of films or television shows I write, I usually try to find at least one good or redeeming thing to say... There has only been one past instance of my inability to do so (simply because there was no redeeming quality in the work I was reviewing), and I thought I would never run into this problem again. Well I have, and in a worse way than I could ever conceive of...

The allegedly video-game-based horror/action film "House of the Dead", from director Uwe Boll (first sign it is a terrible movie... it is from a director with multiple bottom-100 films, and has (so far) never made a movie that scored above a 5-average on IMDb) is honestly the worst of the worst.

The plot revolves around an evil Spanish man named Castillo, who created a blood serum years and years ago (because as we all know, the Spanish had genetic experimentation capabilities hundreds of years ago, or so director Boll would like us to think) that renders him immortal, and turns the deceased into brainless zombies that do his bidding. Or something equally as ludicrous. (Why the zombies immediately serve Castillo like dogs is never explained... because it can't be explained, it makes no sense.) Flash forward to now... A large group of kids are holding the "rave of the century" on a remote island (Yeah, sure... makes perfect sense), with no cell-phone reception, no residents, and no way to get help.

Of course, it turns out Castillo runs the island and slaughters everyone with the aid of his minions.

Then, the "real heroes" (I use that term loosely) show up, because they were conveniently late, and arrive on the island with a crazy old captain (named Captain Kirk, who also, conveniently, is an illegal gun runner with enough weapons to start a military coup) that was nice enough to give them a ride.

From that point on, the kids realize what is going on; some of the more disposable characters (including several survivors who show up) are killed; and the movie takes off. They arm themselves with Kirk's insane amount of weapons, and rather than leave, decide to stay... why? I couldn't tell you, again it makes no sense.

From then on, the movie degenerates into a cruddy shoot-'em-up-fest... And little else...

Now, I don't want to ruin the riveting plot line, but I will say I never realized zombies know how to sword-fight and use kung-fu so well! Alright, enough of this merry synopsis, let's get down to the crap...

-The worst acting I have seen in some time... Even for a horror film this is bad. Case in point... After seeing one of their best friends get killed, the characters simply stroll off, as though it was no big deal. Then, about five minutes later, one of them says "Oh, I can't believe so-and-so died..." and that is it. That is the depth of their emotional abilities as performers... One pathetic, short line and they are over a horrifying ordeal that should be a life-changing event. All I can say is... wow...

-Terrible story and writing... I cannot say enough bad things about the script by Mark Altman and Dan Bates. It has the psychological depth of a Twinkie, and enough lame-brained (and very unfunny) one-liners to sink a ship.

-Uwe's Direction... What truly sets this film apart from other awful films is the atrocity of the direction. Boll apparently tried to add glee and giddiness whilst directing. You can tell he thought he was making an awesome movie... even though he wasn't. He has the camera zoom, tilt, pan, dolly, fly and spin every opportunity he gets, and he tries to milk the (poorly choreographed) action for all it is worth. But Boll's fatal flaw is that he doesn't understand the concept of pace or being subtle. He simply throws shot after shot at the audience, and it gets boring really quick. He uses "Matrix" shots more than the actual "Matrix" movie, he constantly does this lame trick where the camera spins around the actors in slow motion, and for some reason, he thought mixing in a bunch of actual video game footage was a great idea. To be blunt, he simply can't direct action...

It is really apparent by the time the credits roll that Uwe Boll is without a doubt one of the worst directors of all time. I wouldn't even put him in a room with Ed Wood, as many suggest, because Wood's movies were so bad they became humorous, and that makes them work in a (unintended) sense. Boll's films are so bad, you feel like causing yourself bodily harm to distract yourself from the dim-witted images he tosses at you.

Overall, I can say, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that "House of the Dead" is the worst movie I have ever seen... Honestly, for your own sake, avoid this at all costs! (Zero out of Ten)

There are a lot of low quality trash movies to speak of, but the worst one in recent memory would have to be The House of the Dead. This movie was ludicrous in every way imaginable. Which brings me to ask, was this movie meant to be a joke?? I CANT BELIEVE IT MADE IT TO THEATERS!!!! Whoever was responsible for releasing this movie should be imprisoned, seriously. As for the acting of the all no-name cast, let me put it this way, the acting was better in the video game. The characters were unbelievably stupid, yet somehow became experts at weaponry and warfare once guns were placed in their hands. Hell, the nudity could have even been better. This movie will be out on video very very soon. And God help us if they make any sequels. In Summary: Smelly pile of steaming vomit. review_title: Makes you want to shoot a nailgun into your eyes
review_detailed_main:
House of the Dead...

One day, through the miracle of satellite T.V., this movie will reach the depths of space to some alien civilization. With curiosity, they will watch this strange signal from another world, and afterwards they will come to Earth and annihilate humanity for polluting the cosmos with this garbage.

review_title: Please do not waste your time....
The dead walk... you eject the DVD...

review_detailed_main:
A group of young people get an invitation to a rave party on an isolated island. They miss the boat. Simon (Tyron Leitso) tries to get a ride from fisherman Salish (Clint Howard). Captain Kirk (Jürgen Prochnow) accepts $1000 despite the rumored evil spirits. They are pursued by a local Coast Guard officer. None of them know that the island has been invaded by zombies. They arrive to find the place trashed and seemingly abandoned.

This Uwe Boll film is generally a low grade B-movie adapted from a video game. His reputation is well deserved. His camera work is amateurish and flat. One particular sequence almost made me seasick. At first, I thought it to be artistic shaky camera but it's more likely sea swell shaking the docks. His filming of the kills are really poor with no tension. It's got all the hallmarks of a bad B-movie. The zombie makeup is student level. The unimaginative story is flat and convoluted at the same time. The actors are mostly fine TV level workers but nobody is winning any awards in this one. The actresses have boobs and some of them show them off. You may recognize Erica Durance from Smallville. The bad movie list is almost entirely checked off. There are sequences of game play weirdly inserted into the movie to accentuate the Sega game. The spinning action scenes do nothing but get boring and dizzying. It's a Matrix wannabe fail. This is all bad but I've seen worst.

This movie is terrible....just bad. When the movie starts it looks to be a somewhat promising film, no 10 star by any means, but decent. then people start talking...and then the "zombies" show up... and then the terrible effects start happening...and then you feel like your head is going to explode because this movie is so laughably bad. This movie is a gem though if you are into "so bad its good" humor, thats the only way I'd recommend this film. My friend and I use this movie as a punchline to our jokes its that bad.

P.S. If you do choose to watch this, pay close attention to the last line made by the main character and the stupidity of it will sum up the movie better than any other IMDb comment.

A tour de force. A magnificent film., better than the Exorcist. I was riveted throughout the film. I was unable to eat my popcorn for fear of missing a spine-tingling moment. I don't know how Uwe does it. The man's a f***king genius. I really don't know how he can top this film, but I know he will. It's a pity he didn't direct House of the Dead 2. I can't wait for the Directors Cut. It should be f***ing great. This movie is a classic. I've watched it 30 times, and each time I find something new. It's the movie that keeps giving. Tarantino, Romero, Rodriquez watch out. There's new kid on the block - Uwe Boll. You won't find this film in the bargain bin anytime soon. The depth of the acting was sublime. Uwe managed the fine balance between horror and humor with panache and elegance, with a keen understanding of the human condition. Boll is the Tennessee Williams of the horror genre.

Being a fan of the Game that this movie is based off of I really wanted to see this movie. I saw it for $6.99 so I picked it up. I really didn't expect it to be that good because a lot of movies that are based on games usually aren't that good, but has got to be one of the worst movies I've ever seen. The "House" of the Dead, looks more like "Shed" of the Dead and the acting and dialogue were abysmal. Almost the whole movie takes place on a deserted island where supposedly there was supposed to be "the party of the year" but there's nothing more then a little camp site, with a little stage. This movie is total garbage and doesn't have one bit of entertainment value whatsoever. Great game, terrible movie.

I don't think this falls into the category of "so bad it is good," it is simply craptacular. #29 on the worst movies of all time list, and deservedly so seeing as they had a decent enough budget. And really, how hard is it to make a zombie movie? The whole video game homage thing going on was weak as a concept, much less in execution. I saw on the "Man on Fire" comment board that people were claiming that as the worst movie ever... seriously, they must be watching only the best cinema out there if they think Denzel's latest foray holds a candle to this bag of pus. (sigh) I know a LOT of aspiring filmmakers who would have loved to have even a tenth of the cash they blew on this movie, and could turn out quite a decent flick in return...

review_title: Not very lively....even for a movie about the living dead!
review_detailed_main: This film is a perfect example of one of the films which is bottom of the barrel. Its story line is painfully lackluster and its actors aren't the best in a long line of acting names, even the names in the roster for community theater. The plot is somewhat simplistic and it does little to justify the film as a whole. "House of the Dead" is the generic 'college kids go to island and are attacked by monsters' drivel which we've seen for ages yet. It revolves around a group of college students going to a raver on an island and expect good times, but find nothing more than the dead coming to life and attacking them left and right. It seems that these creatures attack for no known reason. While the effects are quite the thing to behold, it seems clear that the rest of the film is not the best...even of the worst. Finally, though the film has a few gunslinging moments that are not to be missed, it is ultimately somewhat forgettable when it comes to horror stories. Or sci-fi stories. Or action- adventure stories...or any story.

Oh my goodness! I have honestly never seen so many people walk out of a movie theatre in history. There was a constant stream like a fast flowing river of people rushing down the cinema aisles! I stuck the movie out but just because I have a policy. The policy is to never walk out of a film - you never know it may get better. OK so that didn't happen on this occasion.

For those of you who haven't seen this film, it is about a group of rich students who want to go to a rave on an island and it turns out there are a bunch of dead guys killing everyone. To be honest with you... that's about as far as the plot goes. The acting in this film is dire. It is full of poor one liners and cheesy lines. So many flaws: OK, these students get a lift with a fisherman who is wanted by this cop woman for smuggling weapons - SMUGGLING WEAPONS! He had 3 wooden boxes each with 1 gun in! They were going to what was supposed to be the biggest rave of the century - there looked like there was about 12 people there - I've had bigger garden parties!

Before I saw this movie someone said to me - it's dawn of the dead meets The Matrix - how I laughed. The reference to the matrix is bullet time - really bad bullet time at that, and the reference to Dawn of the Dead is dead people. This movie had lots of killing of dead people - the fighting scenes were so messy - they were just a series of close ups all muddled up with some bullet time thrown in.

I have a UGC Unlimited card so was not too riled by the fact that I saw this film however, I feel sorry for any paying cinema goer who paid six English pounds to see this drivel!

review_title: Uwe Boll? Might as well have been MANUTE Bol...
review_detailed_main:
Oh. My. God. This movie was terrible - even worse than I expected. At least they got the gratuitous nudity in early on, and Clint Howard made his seventeen zillionth cameo - but holy CRAP, that was terrible.

The friggin' cuts to scenes from the House of the Dead Sega game were mystifying... as in, "Why the heck did they put those shots of the game in the film? Was it to show us that at least the VIDEO GAME had some moments of suspense? UGH!"

Boll clearly does NOT understand pacing, how to establish mood, or even how to build up a feeling of dread within the viewer, knowing that something bad is going to happen, but not expecting when. Lemme tell ya, something BAD happened, all right - this movie got MADE in the first place!

I really don't know where to begin describing how horrible this thing was - the score seemed to be written by the same guy that did the Scooby Doo cartoons, and since there was a Scooby Doo reference in the flick, I wouldn't be surprised if that was indeed the case. In the big fight scene with all the stupid 360 degree shots (yup, another Matrix/Bullet Time steal), the zombies would (in most cases) just walk past "our heroes", I suppose to go after other, more well-armed prey - yep, the ones that would be better suited to blow their heads off.

Even opportunities that the "director" had to give us some cheap scares (like when the lady cop was under the blanket - I figured for SURE she'd crawl out from it and attack "Curien" and his woman), he chose not to. Or when "Liberty" or the black girl are killed, you think that perhaps they will join the zombie hordes, but nope, they just stay dead, never to reappear.

Of course, the dialogue was completely laughable - there are so many examples to cite, that I can't even specify one, although that "here's an old book - maybe it will help us" was particularly memorable. The makeup was probably left over from school projects Tom Savini did when he was in Kindergarten. Oh, and the stunts and action scenes? It looks like everyone that goes to a rave is an action star that "knows kung fu" - heck, even the ZOMBIES seemed to know their martial arts. Let's not forget the foreshadowing - one of the first lines Rudy Curien says is that he broke up with his girlfriend to concentrate on his studies, and so she could focus on her fencing. "I don't see how that's useful", he tells us, and it was pretty obvious that her fencing "skills" would come up later in the film. I was right, but when watching that scene, I thought to myself, "looks like she needs a LOT more training!". Of course, when they show the group of friends during his voice-over, he mentions that they're all dead now - which is an EXCELLENT way of establishing dramatic tension. Not that you could possibly care for these characters, as it is... even if his ex-g.f. was amply endowed.

Anyhow, I could go on, but I've wasted enough of my life on this film. Yes, the two hours I've spent watching and then immediately typing out this stern warning is already too much. Fortunately, I didn't have to pay to rent it - it's on my digital cable movie package this month. Mind you, I think I would have demanded a refund of my rental money as well as the gas to get to and from the video store had I actually rented this tripe. Either that, or forced the video store clerks to WATCH this crap a la Malcolm McDowell in "A Clockwork Orange" - but that would have been just cruel. Really, the person who should have been forced to watch this in that fashion SHOULD be Uwe Boll, with a roomful of disgruntled moviegoers asking him every two seconds this pertinent question:

"WHAT WERE YOU THINKING??"

Yeesh.

review_title: "House Of The Dead"- 6/10. Absolutely horrible, but still enjoyable despite it's flaws.
review_detailed_main:
House Of The Dead (2004)

This movie begins with this group of friends who get a ride on a boat to an island for a rave. When they arrive there, they find no one and meet up with a cop, Jordan Casper (Ellie Cornell- Halloween 4 & 5), and a group of other people who where at the rave when walking dead zombies murdered everyone, turning them into zombies and multiplying there kind. The group fights the zombies with all the weapons they can (mostly guns), and barricade themselves in a house on the island.

This movie has mostly ideas that have been recycled over and over again. It uses Romero's Night of the Living Dead premise, where the gang is locked inside the house with zombies trying to break in. Director Uwe Boll adds in clips of the video game in between shots to remind us of the film's basis, which is pretty dull if you think about it, but it gives it a bit of a unique edge. The acting is mostly horrible, except for Jonathan Cherry (Final Destination 2, They) and Clint Howard, but the rest of the actors are your basic Friday the 13th stupid teenagers who can't act their way out of a paper bag. The movie serves up a lot of gore, so it makes up for some of it's flaws. I hope to see a bit better from Uwe Boll in his upcoming "Alone In The Dark" film that is, again based on a video game.

All in all, the story is overused and getting dull, the acting is mostly terrible, the dialogue is dumb, but it's still one of those movies you can still like for what it is, despite it's flaws. It can be enjoyable, just don't take it seriously. 6/10.

review_title: Watching this actually makes you feel like a zombie...
review_detailed_main:
THIS MOVIE WAS RATED 0 OUT OF 10 BUT THE LOWEST SCORE IMDb HAS IS A 1!

I have to start off the review by saying this is just plain awful, it's just so bad on every level. The story has absolutely nothing in common with the game except for the fact that there are zombies. The only reason you know it's a video game adaptation of House of the Dead because they annoyingly use gameplay clips of the games too much. I also hated the fact that all of the characters suddenly knew how to fight, every single one of them were pulling off kung-fu moves here, there and everywhere and they suddenly learned how to fire a gun and reload fast and how to use a sword. If you thought the voice-over guy in the trailer was bad, it has nothing on the dialogue. The dialogue, the script and the direction was a total nonsense. The acting was just horrible from start to finish, it felt like a terrible no-budget horror movie that you bought from Poundland. It's just rubbish. It was boring, it didn't bring nothing new or special to the table, it didn't follow the game at allan utter waste of my time. The most irritating thing about the movie was the fact that it was meant to be a video game adaptation and yet it didn't follow the games at all, not even the characters were named after them. The only way you knew that it was House of the Dead and not something else was the constant, annoying gameplay footage being shown through the game whenever a zombie was nearby or when an action scene was coming up. I really can't see anybody liking this whatsoever. If you like absolutely terrible, cheesy horror movies then you might like this but even then, you might hate it. I've seen better, MUCH better.

The cop lady takes out her "stainless steel" shotgun with explosive rounds and shows it off to everyone else. Then, Captian Kirk opens his crate where he has a "small" arsenal. The black chick reaches in and grabs a handgun, where after Kirk says "Desert Eagle, I like the way you think." After, we go through a small montage of each character reaching into Kirk's endless crate of weapons and taking something. They pulled out chain-linked bullets, but never a chain-gun. We see one of the characters take some grenades and strap them to her belt. It always surprises me that the US Army spends millions training its troops in proper grenade use but drunk teen-age girls going to a wave already know how. In fact, the characters in this movie strap themselves so full with weapons like sub-machine guns and TNT sticks but never really use them. This scene sucks all the masculinity out of guns that after when I was watching Scarface the last scene wasn't very exciting for me. "House of the Dead" is not only a movie that destroys itself, it also destroys every other movie you'll see. It a cinema-virus.

review_title: Warning: this film will give you intellectual diarrhoea
review_detailed_main:
House of The Dead was the title of a famous video game developed by Rikya Nakagawa of SEGA. The game was designed as a first-person shooter, but what made it stand out from titles such as DOOM and QUAKE was that it was done in arcade format, known to many as the light gun, where rather than sitting back with a controller, the user can hold a gun within his/her own hands and try their best to survive against a horde of undead. This, along with the graphics, the obscene creatures and violence, made the game very popular. The story revolved around two government agents wearing trench coats investigating a mansion, where experiments conducted on zombies goes awry. Curiously, this came out at the same time with Resident Evil, which was more atmospheric.

Now comes the film. Originally DreamWorks had the license, but later lost the rights, which were promptly bought by MINDFIRE's Mark Altman, who would serve as the co-writer and producer of this film. At first I was excited, for I loved Free Enterprise, which Altman had co-written with the director. Later, there were advertisements that showed a Robert Deniro-like zombie licking a girl's face, a scene that could have chilled the audience. However, after watching the film, this viewer, along with many others, emerged disappointed. The plot made absolutely no sense, the acting was poor, and although at times the creatures looked decent, Boll's lighting and directing made them laughable. What further weakened the film was the inclusion of video game footage and MATRIX shots, followed by scenes that were supposedly made to scare the audience. It's almost as if director Uwe Boll hadn't wanted to make a good film; rather, he just wanted to dazzle his audience. His interviews amusingly denied that it was a poorly-made film, making both this garbage and Boll even more pretentious than one would dare to attribute. As a fan of the games, one cannot help but miss the memorable nemeses that were in the game, particularly bosses like the Chariot and the Magician. As a fan of films, I'd occasionally enjoy a cheesy (and sometimes retarded) film, but with Boll's less than stellar hand, this film almost seemed to be a tragedy, for it could have been a fun horror film like EVIL DEAD. I do not deny that Boll is a movie fan, I only question his ability to direct.

As a side-note, the writer's commentary on the DVD was interesting, for it explained what he had wanted to write. One could not help but feel sorry that his script was given to such an awful director, and that it had such a low budget, for it sounded quite promising. However, Altman does manage to redeem himself with the more mindlessly enjoyable HOUSE OF THE DEAD 2. Boll, on the other hand, continues to do video game adaptations, which includes FAR CRY, BLOODRAYNE, ALONE IN THE DARK, Dungeon Siege, and POSTAL, where in a bizarre publicity stunt he challenged his critics to a boxing match.

review_title: I don't understand, I really don't understand
